Chapter 4: Planning & Budgeting in Profitability Analysis

Analyzing actuals is only half the story. A complete solution requires the ability to plan and budget future profitability and then compare those plans to actual results. The original "S4H CLUB" project deferred this functionality, but in a modern S/4HANA landscape, it's a critical component.

4.1. The Modern, Strategic Approach: SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

For S/4HANA, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is the strategic, go-forward solution for all financial planning, including profitability planning.

Concept: Instead of using older, transaction-based planning tools within S/4HANA, the process is integrated with the cloud. This provides a superior user experience, more powerful modeling capabilities, and advanced analytics.

The Process Flow:

  1. Data Replication: Actuals data (and master data) from your S/4HANA Margin Analysis is replicated to SAC. This is a standard integration.
  2. Planning in SAC: Planners, such as sales managers, use intuitive, web-based SAC dashboards and input forms to create their sales and margin plans. They can plan at any level of detail (e.g., by customer group and product family).
  3. Advanced Modeling: SAC allows for complex calculations, simulations ("what-if" analysis), and predictive forecasting to assist in the planning process.
  4. Write-Back: Once the plan is finalized and approved in SAC, it is written back to a specific plan/budget version within S/4HANA's core tables.
  5. Plan/Actual Reporting: You can then run reports in S/4HANA Fiori or SAC to compare your planned profitability against the actuals as they occur.

Relevant SAP Best Practice Scope Item: 4_1 (Sales Planning)

4.2. Classic Planning Framework (For Context)

While SAC is the future, S/4HANA still contains the "classic" CO-PA planning framework (KEPM). This tool allows you to define planning levels, create data entry layouts (similar to spreadsheets), and enter plan data directly within the S/4HANA system.

While powerful, its user interface is dated, and it lacks the collaborative and advanced analytical features of SAC. For new implementations, SAC is the highly recommended path.

Chapter 5: Period-End Closing for Margin Analysis

Margin Analysis isn't just about real-time postings from sales. To get a complete profitability picture, you must perform period-end closing activities to allocate costs that aren't directly tied to a single sales transaction.

5.1. Overview of Period-End Activities

Here is a typical checklist of month-end steps for the CO-PA closing process:

  1. Settle production order variances to CO-PA.
  2. Settle internal orders (e.g., marketing campaigns, R&D projects) to CO-PA.
  3. Allocate overhead costs from cost centers (e.g., corporate HR, finance) to CO-PA using assessment cycles.
  4. Perform any top-down distribution of aggregated data.
  5. Reconcile Margin Analysis with the General Ledger.

5.2. Key Processes Explained

  1. Settlement of Production Variances
  • Concept: During production, differences between planned (standard) costs and actual costs create variances (e.g., using more material or labor than planned). These variances must be reflected in your profitability analysis to show the true cost of sales.
  • Transaction: CO88 (Collective Settlement)
  • Process: When you settle a production order, the total variance is posted to FI/CO and also to Margin Analysis. You must configure which value fields will receive these variance postings (e.g., a "Price Variance" value field and a "Quantity Variance" value field). This ensures your product-level profitability is adjusted for manufacturing performance.
  1. Overhead Allocation with Assessment Cycles
  • Concept: Not all costs can be directly traced to a product. For example, the cost of your central marketing department benefits all product lines. An assessment cycle is a rule that allocates these pooled costs to CO-PA segments based on a logical driver (a "tracer").
  • Example: Allocate the total cost of the Marketing cost center ($500,000) to various product hierarchies based on the revenue generated by each.
  • Customizing & Execution:
    • Define Cycle (KSU1):
      • Sender: Marketing Cost Center, Cost Element Group for marketing expenses.
      • Receiver: CO-PA segments defined by characteristics (e.g., Product Hierarchy).
      • Tracer: The basis for allocation (e.g., the VVREV - Revenue value field).
    • Execute Cycle (KSU5): Run the cycle at month-end to perform the allocation. This creates new CO-PA documents that debit the product lines with their share of marketing costs, providing a more complete "fully-costed" margin.

5.3. The Golden Rule: Reconciliation with Financial Accounting

  • Concept: Because Margin Analysis uses its own value field structure, its total profit figure will not match the General Ledger's operating profit by default. Discrepancies can arise from timing differences or configuration gaps. A month-end reconciliation is mandatory to ensure the integrity of your reporting.
  • Tool: The primary tool is the Reconciliation Ledger. You can create a report that compares the G/L account balances for revenue and cost accounts with the sum of the corresponding value fields in Margin Analysis.
  • Transaction: KE5U or dedicated Fiori reporting.
  • Process: Run the report and analyze the differences. For example, if the "Sales Revenue" G/L account shows $10M but the sum of your CO-PA revenue value fields is $9.9M, you have a $100k difference to investigate. This ensures that your detailed profitability view is consistent with your legally reported financial statements.

Chapter 6: Reporting and Analytics - Turning Data into Insight

All this data is useless if you can't access it in a flexible, user-friendly way. S/4HANA has fundamentally changed reporting from static, transaction-based reports to dynamic, real-time analytics.

6.1. The Old World (Still Available): Report Painter

  • Concept: Report Painter (KE30) was the classic tool for building CO-PA reports. It uses a row/column structure where you define "Forms" to structure the report and then generate the final report from the form. The "S4H CLUB" project heavily referenced these custom Z... reports.
  • Relevance Today: While still functional in S/4HANA for compatibility, it is considered a legacy tool. It produces static reports, has a clunky interface, and lacks the drill-down and visualization capabilities of modern tools. It is not recommended for new report development.
  • Example Translation: The requirement "PNL (Socit)" (PNL by Company) would be a simple Report Painter report with Key Figures (Revenue, COGS, Margin) in the rows and Company Code (BUKRS) as the main characteristic in the columns or navigation block.

6.2. The New World: SAP Fiori Analytical Apps

This is the standard and preferred way to analyze profitability data in S/4HANA. These apps leverage the speed of the HANA database to provide real-time, multidimensional analysis directly from the universal journal.

Key Fiori Apps for Margin Analysis:

  • Market Segments - Actuals: This is your primary tool. It's a powerful and flexible "slice-and-dice" report.
    • Features:
      • You can choose from any characteristic in your operating concern to add to your report rows, columns, or filters.
      • You can choose any value field or create on-the-fly calculations (e.g., Margin % = Gross Margin / Net Revenue).
      • Seamless drill-down from an aggregated total down to the original line items (KE24 view) and even to the source billing document or FI journal entry.
      • Instantly switch between chart and table views.
      • Save your personalized report views and share them with colleagues.
  • Profitability Dashboard: Provides a high-level overview of key profitability KPIs with graphical visualizations.
  • Manage KPIs and Reports: A framework that allows key users to define their own analytical queries and build reports without complex technical knowledge.

6.3. Strategic Analytics: SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

For the most advanced use cases, SAC is the premium tool.

  • Live Connection: SAC can connect live to your S/4HANA system. This means there is no data replication, and you are always analyzing the most current data.
  • Advanced Visualization: Build sophisticated, interactive dashboards that combine profitability data with data from other sources (e.g., CRM, logistics).
  • Predictive Analytics: Use built-in machine learning capabilities to forecast future sales and margins.
  • Enterprise Reporting: Create "board-room ready" reports and stories that can be shared across the organization.

Reporting Strategy for Global S4H CLUB:

  1. Operational Reporting: All day-to-day analysis by product managers, sales reps, and controllers will be done using the Market Segments - Actuals Fiori App.
  2. Executive Dashboards & Planning: High-level dashboards and the entire planning process will be managed in SAP Analytics Cloud.
  3. Legacy Reports: Existing Report Painter reports will be kept for a short time for reference but will be systematically migrated to Fiori or SAC.

    * Verify that the key figures in the report match the expected results. Use the "View By" options to display the data by Customer Group and Product Hierarchy to confirm those characteristics were populated.

Test Scenario 2: Testing Period-End Overhead Allocation

  • Objective: To verify that central overhead costs can be allocated correctly to the product lines based on revenue.
  • Test Data:
    • Sender Cost Center: CC-MKT-EU (European Marketing)
    • Amount to Allocate: €100,000
    • Allocation Basis (Tracer): Gross Revenue
    • Receivers: All profitability segments.

Test Steps:

  1. Post Costs (Prerequisite):
    • App: Post General Journal Entries (FB50)
    • Action: Post a €100,000 expense (e.g., advertising) to the cost center CC-MKT-EU.
  2. Define Assessment Cycle (One-time setup):
    • Transaction: KSU1
    • Action: Create a cycle EU_MKT_ALLOC.
    • Define the sender (CC-MKT-EU) and the receiver (characteristics Product Hierarchy and Company Code).
    • Set the Tracing Factor to be the value field VVREV (Gross Revenue).
  3. Execute Assessment Cycle:
    • Transaction: KSU5
    • Action: Execute the cycle EU_MKT_ALLOC for the current period in "Test Run" mode first.
    • Verification (Test Run): Review the output log. The system should show how it plans to split the €100,000 among the different product hierarchies based on the revenue they generated in the period (including the revenue from Test Scenario 1).
    • Action (Production Run): Once the test run is satisfactory, execute the cycle in production mode (uncheck "Test Run").
  4. Final Verification:
    • App: Market Segments - Actuals
    • Action: Run a report for the product GV-PUMP-02. You should now see a value in the value field you designated for marketing overhead costs. The total profit for this product will be reduced, reflecting a more accurate, fully costed margin.

This concludes the comprehensive guide and test plan. By following these steps, Global S4H CLUB Inc. can successfully implement and leverage SAP S/4HANA Margin Analysis to drive smarter, more profitable business decisions.

    • Test Scenario 6: Sales Returns and Credit Memos
  6. Appendix

    • Key Transactions and Fiori Apps

Part 1: Foundational Concepts

Chapter 1: What is Profitability Analysis (CO-PA)?

Imagine you are the CEO of Global Components Inc. (GCI), a company that manufactures and sells high-tech electronic components. At the end of the month, your standard financial statements tell you that the company made a total profit of $10 million. This is good to know, but it doesn't answer the crucial questions:

  • Which products are the most profitable? Is it our high-volume "Standard Widget" or our high-margin "Pro Widget"?
  • Which customers or customer groups generate the most profit? Are our large distributors more profitable than our direct-to-consumer sales?
  • Which sales region (e.g., North America, Europe, Asia) is performing the best?
  • What is our profit margin after considering not just manufacturing costs, but also sales commissions, freight, and marketing expenses?

Answering these questions requires a multidimensional view of profitability. Profitability Analysis (CO-PA) is the SAP module designed to provide exactly that. It's an information system that allows you to collect, structure, and analyze your revenues, costs, and margins from various perspectives, known as profitability segments.

In essence, CO-PA is the subledger for profit and loss, breaking down the single "Profit" line on your P&L into meaningful business dimensions.

Chapter 2: The Two Flavors of CO-PA: Margin Analysis vs. Costing-Based

In SAP S/4HANA, CO-PA comes in two forms. It is crucial to understand the difference. The configuration documents provided as a source for this guide are based on the traditional Costing-Based CO-PA, so we will focus on its logic. However, SAP's strategic direction is Margin Analysis (Account-Based CO-PA).

Margin Analysis (Account-Based CO-PA)

  • How it Works: This form is seamlessly integrated with the General Ledger (G/L). Every time a posting is made to a revenue or cost account, the system can simultaneously post it to CO-PA, enriching the G/L line item with profitability characteristics (customer, product, etc.).
  • Key Feature: It provides a real-time, reconciled view of profitability. The data in CO-PA always matches the data in your official financial statements (FI) because they share the same source table: the Universal Journal (ACDOCA).
  • Structure: It uses G/L Accounts as the primary structure for costs and revenues.

Costing-Based CO-PA

  • How it Works: This form uses its own data structures and is not directly tied to G/L accounts. It uses Value Fields to store cost and revenue information. Data is transferred from other modules (like Sales & Distribution) into these value fields at the point of a business event (e.g., when a customer invoice is created).
  • Key Feature: Its greatest strength is the ability to break down the Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) into its detailed components (e.g., material costs, labor costs, overhead) using the product cost estimate. It can also incorporate statistical or predictive values that might not be in the G/L.
  • Structure: It uses Value Fields, which are independent of the Chart of Accounts.

Feature

Margin Analysis (Account-Based)

Costing-Based CO-PA

SAP's Focus

Strategic & Recommended

Supported, classic approach

Data Source

Universal Journal (ACDOCA)

Separate CO-PA tables

Reconciliation with FI

Always reconciled by design

Periodic reconciliation required

COGS Breakdown

Possible, but requires more setup

Standard functionality

Primary Structure

G/L Accounts

Value Fields

Data Timing

Real-time at time of posting

Often at time of billing/settlement

This guide will focus on the logic and configuration of Costing-Based CO-PA, as it mirrors the source documents, but will provide notes on how concepts relate to Margin Analysis where relevant.

Chapter 3: The Core Building Blocks of CO-PA

Regardless of the type you use, CO-PA is built on three fundamental concepts:

  1. Operating Concern: This is the highest-level organizational unit in CO-PA1. Think of it as the data warehouse for all your profitability data. An operating concern contains all the characteristics and value fields that define your profitability reporting structure. A company can have one or more operating concerns, but a single, global operating concern is the best practice.
  2. Characteristics: These are the dimensions by which you want to analyze profitability2. They answer the "who, what, and where" of a transaction.
    • Examples: Customer, Product, Sales Region, Country, Distribution Channel, Product Hierarchy.
    • SAP provides many pre-defined characteristics, but you can also create your own user-defined ones to meet specific business needs.
  3. Value Fields (for Costing-Based CO-PA): These are the containers for the figures you want to analyze. They answer the "how much" of a transaction3.
    • Examples: Revenue, Sales Quantity, Customer Discount, Freight Cost, Raw Material Cost, Labor Cost.
    • They can hold monetary amounts or quantities.

These three blocks combine to create a Profitability Segment. A profitability segment is a unique combination of characteristic values.

Example:

  • Product: Pro Widget
  • Customer: Tech Corp
  • Country: USA
  • Distribution Channel: Direct Sales

This specific combination forms one profitability segment. For this segment, the system will then record the values in the value fields:

  • Revenue: $10,000
  • Sales Quantity: 100 units
  • Customer Discount: $500
  • COGS - Materials: $3,000
  • COGS - Labor: $1,500

By collecting data in this structured way, you can later run reports that aggregate or slice this data however you need.

Part 2: Designing Your Profitability Model

Before a single transaction can be posted, you must design and build the structure of your profitability analysis. This is the most critical phase and involves defining the operating concern and its components.

Chapter 4: Defining the Operating Concern - The Foundation

The operating concern is the environment that holds your entire CO-PA structure4. Setting it up is the first step in configuration.

Our Scenario: Global Components Inc. needs a global operating concern to analyze its worldwide business. We will call it GCI1.

How-To: Create and Configure the Operating Concern

  • SAP GUI Transaction: KEA0
  • SPRO Path: Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Structures > Define Operating Concern > Maintain Operating Concern

Step 1: Create the Operating Concern

In KEA0, you will create a new entry for GCI1.

Step 2: Define the Data Structure

This is where you decide which Characteristics and Value Fields will be part of your operating concern.

  • On the right side, you'll see a list of all available characteristics (e.g., KNDNR for Customer, ARTNR for Product). You will select the ones GCI needs for its analysis and move them to the left side ("Data structure").
  • You will do the same for Value Fields (e.g., ERLOS for Revenue, ABSMG for Sales Quantity) on the "Value Fields" tab. We will cover creating custom ones in the next chapters.

Step 3: Define Attributes

Here you set the basic properties of the operating concern:

  • Operating Concern Currency: We'll set this to USD (US Dollar), as GCI is a US-based multinational. Even if transactions happen in other currencies, they will all be translated and stored in USD within CO-PA5.
  • Fiscal Year Variant: We'll use K4 (Calendar Year, 12 periods and 4 special periods), which is a common standard6. This determines your posting periods.

Step 4: Generate the Environment

Once the structure and attributes are defined, you must save and generate the operating concern. This is a technical step where SAP creates the underlying database tables and programs required to store and process CO-PA data7777. This can take some time to complete.

Chapter 5: Defining Characteristics - The "Who, What, Where"

Characteristics are the soul of your profitability reporting. A good selection of characteristics is key to providing meaningful insights.

Our Scenario: GCI wants to analyze profitability by:

  • Standard dimensions: Customer, Product, Sales Organization, Country.
  • Custom dimensions:
    • Country Group: A way to group countries into larger regions (e.g., NA for North America, EU for Europe)88.
    • Customer Typology: A classification of customers (e.g., 01 for Distributor, 02 for Direct Customer)99.
    • Product Hierarchy: A multi-level product grouping (e.g., Level 1: Product Family, Level 2: Product Type, Level 3: Version)10.

Types of Characteristics

  1. Fixed Characteristics: SAP automatically includes a set of fundamental characteristics in every operating concern (e.g., Company Code, Controlling Area).
  2. Predefined Characteristics: These are characteristics that pull from existing SAP tables, such as Customer (KNDNR from table KNA1) or Product (ARTNR from table MARA).
  3. User-Defined Characteristics: These are custom characteristics you create to meet specific business needs11. Our "Country Group" and "Customer Typology" are examples. They usually start with "WW" as per older conventions but can be named freely in modern systems.

How-To: Create a User-Defined Characteristic

Let's create the G_CTRYGP (Country Group) characteristic.

  • SAP GUI Transaction: KEA5
  • SPRO Path: Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Structures > Define Operating Concern > Maintain Characteristics
  1. Create: Enter a name like G_CTRYGP and click Create.
  2. Description: Provide a meaningful description, e.g., "GCI Country Group".
  3. Data Type & Length: Define the technical attributes. We can make it a Character field of length 4 (CHAR 4).
  4. Origin: For a user-defined characteristic, you specify that you will maintain its values yourself. You will create a

check table and a text table12. This allows you to define the valid entries (e.g., NA, EU, APAC) and their descriptions.

  1. Save and Activate: Once defined, you must save and activate the characteristic.

How-To: Maintain Characteristic Values

For user-defined characteristics like G_CTRYGP, you need to populate the valid values.

  • SAP GUI Transaction: KES1 13
  • SPRO Path: Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Master Data > Characteristic Values > Maintain Characteristic Values

In this transaction, you would select your characteristic G_CTRYGP and enter the values and their descriptions:

  • NA: North America
  • EU: European Union
  • APAC: Asia-Pacific

For characteristics that are derived from other master data (like

LAND1 for Country), their values are maintained in their source tables automatically (e.g., country codes are standard SAP content)14. Some characteristics, like those for

Country Group and Customer Typology, require manual maintenance because they are specific to CO-PA and not updated by other modules15151515.

Chapter 6: Defining Value Fields - The "How Much"

Value fields are the buckets that hold the monetary and quantity data in Costing-Based CO-PA16.

Our Scenario: GCI needs to track the following key figures:

  • Quantities: Sales Quantity
  • Revenues: Gross Revenue, Customer Rebates, Net Revenue
  • Cost of Goods Sold (COGS): Broken down into Material Costs, Labor Costs, Overhead Costs.
  • Other Costs: Freight, Sales Commissions.

How-To: Create a Value Field

Let's create a value field for "Sales Commissions".

  • SAP GUI Transaction: KEA6 17
  • SPRO Path: Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Structures > Define Operating Concern > Maintain Value Fields
  1. Create: You can create a new value field group if needed, then add a value field. User-defined value fields traditionally start with "VV", but let's use a more descriptive name: G_COMMIS.
  2. Description: Enter "Sales Commissions".
  3. Type: Choose whether it's an Amount field or a Quantity field18. For

G_COMMIS, it's an Amount field.

  1. Aggregation Rule: Define how the system should handle this value when summarizing data over time. For most financial fields, this will be

SUM (Addition)19.

  1. Save and Activate: Save your changes.

After creating all necessary characteristics and value fields, you must add them to your operating concern's data structure (KEA0) and regenerate it.

Part 3: Bringing Data to Life - Configuration in Detail

With the structure defined, we now need to configure the rules that will automatically populate it with data from business transactions.

Chapter 7: Characteristic Derivation - The Engine of CO-PA

When a transaction occurs (e.g., a sales invoice is posted), the system might only know a few characteristics directly, like the customer and product.

Characteristic Derivation is the powerful mechanism CO-PA uses to automatically determine the values of other related characteristics20.

It's a strategy composed of a series of steps. The system works through these steps in order to fill in as many blank characteristic fields as possible21.

  • SAP GUI Transaction: KEDR
  • Fiori App: Configure Characteristic Derivation
  • SPRO Path: Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Master Data > Define Characteristic Derivation

Example 1: Deriving "Country Group" (Rule-Based)

Goal: We want the system to automatically determine our custom G_CTRYGP characteristic based on the customer's country (LAND1), which is known from the sales order.

How-To: In transaction KEDR, we will create a derivation step of type "Derivation Rule".

  1. Source Field: LAND1 (Customer Country)
  2. Target Field: G_CTRYGP (GCI Country Group)
  3. Rule Definition: Click on "Maintain Rule Values". Here you create a mapping table:

Source: LAND1

Target: G_CTRYGP

Now, whenever a sale is made to a customer in the US, Canada, or Mexico, CO-PA will automatically populate the Country Group characteristic with "NA"22.

Example 2: Deriving "Product Hierarchy" (Move-Based)

Goal: Our product master contains a standard product hierarchy field (PRDHA) that combines all levels into a single string (e.g., "WIDGET-PRO-V2"). We have created three separate characteristics in CO-PA: G_PRODFAM (Family), G_PRODTYP (Type), and G_PRODVER (Version). We need to split the source field into these three target fields.

How-To: This requires three derivation steps of type "Move".

  1. Step 1 (Derive Product Family):
    • Source: PRDHA
    • Target: G_PRODFAM
    • Rule: Move PRDHA, starting at position 1, for a length of 6 characters. ("WIDGET")
  2. Step 2 (Derive Product Type):
    • Source: PRDHA
    • Target: G_PRODTYP
    • Rule: Move PRDHA, starting at position 8, for a length of 3 characters. ("PRO")
  3. Step 3 (Derive Product Version):
    • Source: PRDHA
    • Target: G_PRODVER
    • Rule: Move PRDHA, starting at position 12, for a length of 2 characters. ("V2")

This type of derivation is extremely useful for restructuring existing data for better analysis23.

Other common derivation types include

"Table Lookup", where the system reads another SAP table to find a value (e.g., looking up the sales office from the customer master table)24, and

"Enhancement", which allows for custom ABAP code for very complex logic.

Chapter 8: Data Flow from Sales (SD) - Mapping Revenues and Discounts

This is where the money comes in. When you create a billing document (invoice) in SD, the values from the pricing procedure must be mapped to your CO-PA value fields.

  • SAP GUI Transaction: KE4I 25
  • SPRO Path: Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Flows of Actual Values > Transfer of Billing Documents > Assign Value Fields

Our Scenario: GCI's SD pricing procedure contains several condition types:

  • ZPR0: Gross Price
  • ZK07: Customer Discount
  • ZFR0: Freight Charge
  • VPRS: Cost of Goods Sold (statistical)

How-To: In KE4I, you map each SD condition type to a CO-PA value field.

SD Condition Type

A Note on Signs: Normally, CO-PA receives all values as positive and knows that discounts and costs should be subtracted from revenue in reports. However, some conditions like discounts are stored as negative values in SD. By checking the "Transfer with sign" box for ZK07, we ensure the value is transferred correctly into CO-PA. In this case, we want discounts to appear as a positive value in their own value field, so we would not check this box. If a single condition type could be a surcharge (+) or a discount (-), we

would check the box to ensure the correct sign is transferred27.

In addition to values, you also map SD quantity fields to CO-PA quantity value fields.

  • SAP GUI Transaction: KE4M 28
  • Mapping: FKIMG (Billed Quantity) -> ABSMG (Sales Quantity) 29

Chapter 9: Data Flow from Production (CO-PC) - Mapping Cost of Goods Sold

To get a true margin, you need to match your revenues with the cost of producing the goods sold (COGS). The best practice is to transfer the detailed Cost Component Split from the product's standard cost estimate into CO-PA.

  • SAP GUI Transaction: KE4R 30
  • SPRO Path: Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Flows of Actual Values > Transfer of Cost of Goods Sold > Assign Value Fields for Costing Components

Our Scenario: GCI's standard cost estimate for a "Pro Widget" is broken down in the Cost Component Structure as follows:

  • 10: Raw Materials
  • 20: Packaging
  • 30: Direct Labor
  • 40: Machine Overhead

How-To: In KE4R, you map each of these cost components to a CO-PA value field.

This powerful mapping allows you to analyze not just the total COGS, but its underlying structure. You can see if margins are shrinking because of rising material costs or increasing labor expenses. You can also distinguish between fixed and variable costs for contribution margin analysis31.

Chapter 10: Data Flow from Finance (FI) - Direct Postings

Not all costs are related to a specific sales transaction. What about general marketing costs for a product line, or administrative overhead for a sales division? These costs can be posted directly from FI to a profitability segment.

  • SAP GUI Transaction: FB50 (G/L Account Posting), OKB9 (Default Account Assignment)
  • Fiori App: Post General Journal Entries

To enable this, certain cost element categories for G/L accounts must be configured to allow posting to a profitability segment. In transaction OKB9, you can also set up default profitability segments for certain cost elements/company codes to simplify the posting process.

When an accountant posts an expense in FI (e.g., $5,000 to the "Marketing Campaigns" G/L account), they can enter a profitability segment (e.g., Product Family = "WIDGET", Country = "US"). This expense will then flow into the appropriate value field in CO-PA, allowing you to build a full, comprehensive P&L for any slice of your business.

Chapter 11: Configuring Number Ranges for CO-PA Documents

Every posting to CO-PA, whether from SD, FI, or another source, generates a CO-PA document. These documents need a unique number. You must define the number ranges for these documents.

  • SAP GUI Transaction: KEN1 32
  • SPRO Path: Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Flows of Actual Values > Initial Steps > Define Number Ranges for Actual Postings

In this step, you define number range intervals for different record types of CO-PA transactions. For GCI, we will focus on

Record Type 'F', which corresponds to billing data from SD33.

Configuration:

  • For Operating Concern GCI1, create a group for actual postings.
  • Assign Record Type F to this group.
  • Define a number range interval, for example, from 1000000000 to 1999999999.
  • Ensure the numbering is set to

Internal, as the system must assign these numbers automatically when data flows from other modules like SD and FI34.

Part 4: The End-to-End Process in Action at GCI

Now that the configuration is complete, let's see how it all works together in a real-world business scenario.

Chapter 12: Master Data: The Key to Seamless Integration

The quality of your CO-PA data is directly dependent on the quality of your master data.

  • Customer Master (XD01/BP Fiori App):
    • The Country field (LAND1) is critical for our Country Group derivation.
    • The Customer Account Group can be used to derive Customer Typology.
    • The Sales District and Price Group fields are standard characteristics.
  • Material Master (MM01/Manage Product Master Data Fiori App):
    • The Product Hierarchy field (PRDHA) in the "Sales: Sales Org 1" view is the source for our product hierarchy derivation.
    • The Profit Center field in the "Costing 1" view is important for reconciliation with Profit Center Accounting.
  • Standard Cost Estimate (CK11N/CK40N):
    • A valid, released standard cost estimate for the material is mandatory. Without it, the system cannot populate the COGS value fields when the sales invoice is posted. The cost estimate must have the same Cost Component Structure that we mapped in KE4R.

Chapter 13: The Order-to-Cash Cycle: A Transactional Deep Dive

Let's follow a single sale for 10 "Pro Widgets" to customer "Tech Corp" in the USA.

Step 1: Create Sales Order (VA01/Create Sales Orders Fiori App)

  • When you enter the customer (Tech Corp) and material (Pro Widget), the system automatically determines a Profitability Segment on the item's "Account Assignment" tab.
  • At this stage, you can click the "Profit. Segment" button to see the derived characteristics. You should see that the Country is "US", and our derivation rule has correctly filled in Country Group as "NA". The product hierarchy characteristics should also be populated.
  • No financial postings occur yet, but the "blueprint" for the CO-PA posting is created.

Step 2: Create Delivery and Post Goods Issue (VL01N, VL02N/Create Outbound Deliveries Fiori App)

  • When you post the goods issue (PGI), the system takes the goods out of inventory. This triggers a financial posting:
    • Debit: Cost of Goods Sold (G/L Account)
    • Credit: Inventory (G/L Account)
  • At this moment, if Margin Analysis (Account-Based CO-PA) is active, a CO-PA document is generated, posting the COGS to the profitability segment. In traditional Costing-Based CO-PA, this value is often carried over to the billing document and posted to CO-PA at that time.

Step 3: Create Billing Document (VF01/Create Billing Documents Fiori App)

  • This is the key step for Costing-Based CO-PA. When you save the invoice, two critical things happen:
    • Debit: Customer A/R
    • Credit: Sales Revenue
    • Credit: Freight Revenue
    • The system takes the profitability segment from the sales order.
    • It reads the SD pricing conditions and, using the mapping from KE4I, posts the values to the CO-PA value fields:
      • ERLOS: Populated with the value from condition ZPR0.
      • G_REBATE: Populated with the value from ZK07.
      • G_FREIGHT: Populated with the value from ZFR0.
    • It reads the Standard Cost Estimate and, using the mapping from KE4R, posts the COGS components to the CO-PA value fields:
      • G_MATCST: Populated with the material cost components.
      • G_LABCST: Populated with the labor cost components.
      • G_OVHCST: Populated with the overhead cost components.
    • It reads the billed quantity and, using KE4M, populates the ABSMG value field.
    1. Financial Document (FI):
    2. Profitability Document (CO-PA):

You can view the generated CO-PA document from the billing document's "Environment > Document Flow" and drilling into the accounting documents.

Chapter 14: Analyzing Profitability: Reporting and Insights

After transactions have flowed into CO-PA, you can begin your analysis.

  • SAP GUI Transaction: KE24 (Display Actual Line Items)
    • This is the most fundamental report. It allows you to see every single CO-PA document posted to the system. It is invaluable for troubleshooting and validating that your configurations are working correctly. You can filter by any characteristic to find specific transactions.
  • SAP GUI Transaction: KE30 (Execute Profitability Report)
    • This is the classic reporting tool where you build and execute summarized, drill-down reports. You can define reports that start with a high-level view (e.g., total profit by Country Group) and then allow users to drill down into countries, customers, and finally individual products.
  • SAP Fiori Apps:
    • Market Segments - Actuals: This powerful Fiori app is the modern equivalent of KE30. It provides a flexible, dynamic way to analyze your profitability data using a wide range of characteristics and key figures. You can easily switch dimensions, create charts, and export data.
    • Profitability Dashboard: Provides a high-level graphical overview of key profitability KPIs.

Using a report, the GCI CEO can now answer their original questions:

  • They can filter the report by Product to see the total revenue and costs for "Pro Widgets" vs. "Standard Widgets".
  • They can add the Customer characteristic to the report to see that "Tech Corp" is highly profitable.
  • They can view the report by Country Group to compare the performance of North America vs. Europe.

Part 5: Comprehensive Integrated Test Plan

This test plan is designed to validate the entire end-to-end process flow, ensuring that the CO-PA configuration is working as expected.

Test Scenario 1: Master Data Creation and Validation

  • Objective: To ensure all necessary master data is created correctly and contains the fields required for CO-PA derivation and valuation.
  • Test Steps:
    • In the "Sales: Sales Org 1" view, set the Product Hierarchy (PRDHA) to "WIDGET-PRO-V3".
    • Ensure the country is set to DE.
    • Assign an appropriate customer account group.
    1. Create a new material: "PRO-WIDGET-V3" using transaction MM01 or the Fiori App.
    2. Create a standard cost estimate for "PRO-WIDGET-V3" using CK11N and release it using CK24. Ensure the cost estimate contains values for your material, labor, and overhead cost components.
    3. Create a new customer: "Global Tech Inc." in Germany (DE) using transaction XD01 or the BP Fiori App.
  • Expected Results:
    • The material master is saved successfully with the product hierarchy populated.
    • The standard cost estimate is released and visible in the material master's costing view.
    • The customer master is saved successfully with the correct country.

Test Scenario 2: Standard Domestic Sales Process

  • Objective: To validate the flow of revenue, discounts, quantities, and COGS for a standard sale.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Create a sales order (VA01) for the US customer "Tech Corp" for 5 units of "PRO-WIDGET-V3".
    2. On the item's "Account Assignment" tab, check the Profitability Segment.
    3. Create a delivery (VL01N) and post the goods issue.
    4. Create a billing document (VF01).
    5. From the billing document, navigate to the Document Flow and display the Accounting Documents. Find the Profitability Analysis document.
    6. Alternatively, use transaction KE24 to find the line item posted for this billing document.
  • Expected Results:
    • In the Profitability Segment on the sales order, the Country Group should be derived as "NA" and the product hierarchy fields should be split correctly.
    • In the CO-PA line item (KE24), you must verify:
      • The Revenue value field (ERLOS) matches the gross price from the invoice.
      • The Discount value field (G_REBATE) matches the discount from the invoice.
      • The Sales Quantity value field (ABSMG) is 5.
      • The COGS value fields (G_MATCST, G_LABCST, G_OVHCST) are populated with the correct values from the standard cost estimate (multiplied by 5).
      • All characteristics (Customer, Product, Country Group, Product Hierarchy, etc.) are populated correctly.

Test Scenario 3: International Sales with Country Group Derivation

  • Objective: To validate that the characteristic derivation rule for Country Group works for a different region.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Follow the same steps as Test Scenario 2, but create the sales order for the new German customer "Global Tech Inc.".
  • Expected Results:
    • In the Profitability Segment and the final CO-PA line item, the Country characteristic should be "DE".
    • The Country Group characteristic (G_CTRYGP) must be automatically derived as "EU" based on our derivation rule.
    • All value fields should be populated correctly, potentially in EUR and translated to the operating concern currency of USD.

Test Scenario 4: Product Hierarchy Analysis

  • Objective: To validate the derivation of the split product hierarchy and its usefulness in reporting.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Ensure you have transactions posted for different products (e.g., "PRO-WIDGET-V3" and "LITE-WIDGET-V1").
    2. Run a profitability report using the Market Segments - Actuals Fiori App or KE30.
    3. Use the characteristics G_PRODFAM (Product Family), G_PRODTYP (Product Type), and G_PRODVER (Product Version) as report dimensions.
  • Expected Results:
    • The report should correctly display revenues and costs for each level of the product hierarchy.
    • You should be able to drill down from the "WIDGET" family to the "PRO" and "LITE" types, and then to the individual versions, with all figures aggregating correctly.

Test Scenario 5: Direct FI Posting for Marketing Expenses

  • Objective: To validate the flow of costs from a direct FI posting to CO-PA.
  • Test Steps:
    • Product Family (G_PRODFAM): WIDGET
    • Country Group (G_CTRYGP): NA
    1. Use the Post General Journal Entries Fiori App (or FB50).
    2. Debit a marketing expense G/L account for $10,000.
    3. Credit a bank or clearing account.
    4. On the marketing expense line item, click the "Profit. Segment" button and enter the following characteristics:
    5. Post the document.
    6. Check for the posting in transaction KE24.
  • Expected Results:
    • A CO-PA line item is generated with a specific record type for FI postings.
    • The value of $10,000 should appear in the value field mapped to FI postings for marketing.
    • The characteristics for Product Family and Country Group should be populated as entered. This allows you to allocate central costs to specific market segments for a more complete profitability picture.

Test Scenario 6: Sales Returns and Credit Memos

  • Objective: To ensure that returns and credits correctly reverse the values in CO-PA.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Create a returns order (RE) with reference to the original billing document from Scenario 2.
    2. Create a returns delivery and post the goods receipt.
    3. Create a credit memo (G2) with reference to the returns order.
    4. Check for the new CO-PA document generated by the credit memo in KE24.
  • Expected Results:
    • A new CO-PA document is created.
    • The values in this document should be the negative of the original invoice posting. Revenue, COGS, and Quantity value fields should show negative amounts, effectively reversing the original transaction for the returned goods.
    • All characteristics must match the original transaction to ensure the reversal is applied to the correct profitability segment.

Appendix

Glossary of Terms

  • CO-PA (Profitability Analysis): A controlling module for analyzing the profitability of market segments.
  • Operating Concern: The highest organizational unit in CO-PA, defining the structure for analysis.
  • Characteristic: A dimension for profitability analysis (e.g., customer, product, region).
  • Value Field: (Costing-Based CO-PA) A data field that stores a monetary amount or a quantity (e.g., Revenue, COGS, Sales Quantity).
  • Profitability Segment: A unique combination of characteristic values.
  • Derivation: The automatic process of determining characteristic values based on known information.
  • Margin Analysis: The account-based form of CO-PA in S/4HANA, integrated with the Universal Journal.
  • Costing-Based CO-PA: The traditional form of CO-PA that uses value fields and is not directly tied to the G/L.
  • Universal Journal: The single source of truth for financial data in S/4HANA (table ACDOCA).

entry.title: Did You Know? You Can Group Multiple Tabs with Colors in SSC v2—Just Like Chrome!
entry.content:
If you’re a power user of web browsers like Chrome, you probably love the ability to group tabs and color-code them for better organization. But did you know you can do something very similar in SSC v2 (SAP Sales & Service Console version 2)? This handy feature can make your productivity smoother and your workspace much more organized!

Why Tab Grouping Matters

When you’re working on multiple tasks, workspace objects, or environments, your browser (or SSC v2) can quickly become cluttered with dozens of open tabs.

Grouping tabs helps you:

  • Reduce clutter by visually bundling related tabs together.
  • Switch context faster by collapsing or expanding groups as needed.
  • Color-code your work, making it easy to spot the right group at a glance.

How to Group Tabs in SSC v2

SSC v2 has introduced a feature that lets you group multiple open tabs, assign them a name, and even pick a color—just like Chrome’s tab groups! Here’s how you can use it:

1. Open Multiple Tabs

  • Start by opening the tabs you want to group together in SSC v2.

2. Create a Tab Group 

  • Right-click on any tab you want to add to a group.
  • Select “Add to Group” from the context menu.

3. Name and Color Your Group

  • A dialog will appear allowing you to name your group (e.g., “Project Alpha” or “Monitoring”).
  • Choose a color for your group. This color will highlight the group, making it easy to identify.

4. Add More Tabs to the Group

  • To add more tabs, simply drag them into the group or right-click and select “Add to Existing Group.”

5. Manage Your Groups

  • You can collapse or expand groups to save space.
  • Right-click the group label to rename, change color, or remove the group.

Pro Tips

  • Use colors strategically: Assign colors based on project, urgency, or type of work.
  • Collapse groups you’re not using: This keeps your workspace tidy and focused.
  • Mix and match: You can have multiple groups open at once, each with its own color and name.

Final Thoughts

Tab grouping in SSC v2 is a small feature with a big impact. If you haven’t tried it yet, give it a go! You’ll find your productivity/process becomes more organized, efficient, and visually appealing—just like in Chrome, but tailored for your SSC environment.

entry.title: The Ultimate Guide to Product Costing in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Key Objectives of Product Costing:

  • Inventory Valuation: To assign a monetary value to materials held in stock (raw materials, semi-finished goods, finished goods) in compliance with accounting principles (e.g., IFRS, GAAP).
  • Cost Management & Control: To establish a benchmark (a standard cost) against which actual production costs can be measured, allowing for the analysis of variances and the identification of inefficiencies.
  • Profitability Analysis: To provide the Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) for each sale, which is a critical input for determining the profitability of products, customers, and market segments.
  • Pricing & Quotation Support: To provide a solid cost basis for sales and marketing teams to make informed pricing decisions.
  • "What-If" Simulations: To simulate the cost impact of changes in material prices, production processes, or overhead rates.

This guide will walk you through the entire lifecycle of product costing, from the foundational master data and configuration to the execution of costing runs and the critical month-end closing activities. We will also provide a comprehensive, integrated test plan to help you practice and solidify your understanding of these end-to-end processes.

Part I: The Foundation - Master Data & Organizational Structure

Before any costs can be calculated, a solid foundation of organizational and master data must be in place. This data provides the structure and the raw inputs for the costing engine.

Chapter 1: Organizational Structure

The organizational structure defines the legal and business framework in which your company operates.

  • Controlling Area: The highest organizational unit in Controlling. It defines a self-contained costing environment. All objects within a controlling area must use the same Chart of Accounts and Fiscal Year Variant.
  • Company Code: Represents a legal entity for which a complete set of financial statements (Balance Sheet, P&L) is created. Company codes are assigned to a controlling area.
  • Plant: A physical location where production occurs, inventory is stored, or services are rendered. It is the central organizational unit for production and logistics and is assigned to a Company Code. Product costs are typically calculated at the plant level.
  • Storage Location / EWM Warehouse: Subdivisions of a plant where materials are physically stored. While not directly a costing object, they are crucial for inventory management processes that trigger financial postings.

Chapter 2: Core Controlling Master Data

This master data forms the building blocks for collecting and allocating costs.

  • Cost Center (Fiori App: Manage Cost Centers - F1738): A location or department where costs are incurred. Production work centers are linked to cost centers to collect production-related overhead.
  • Activity Type (Fiori App: Manage Activity Types - F2428): Represents the activities performed by a cost center, such as "Machine Hours" or "Labor Hours." They are the mechanism used to allocate costs from cost centers to production orders based on the work performed.
  • Cost Elements / G/L Accounts: In S/4HANA, cost elements are merged with G/L accounts.
    • Primary Cost Elements: Used for posting expenses that originate from outside of Controlling (e.g., FI, MM), such as raw material consumption or vendor invoices.
    • Secondary Cost Elements: Used exclusively within Controlling for internal cost allocations, such as activity allocations or overhead calculations. They do not have a corresponding account in the General Ledger for external reporting but are essential for internal management reporting.

Chapter 3: The Material Master - The Central Object

The Material Master contains all information about a material. For costing, the following views are paramount.

(Fiori App: Create/Change/Display Material - MM01/MM02/MM03)

  • Accounting 1 View:
    • Valuation Class: The most critical link between Materials Management (MM) and Finance (FI). It determines the G/L accounts that are posted during goods movements for this material. For example, all raw materials might be assigned to valuation class 3000, which in turn points to specific inventory and consumption G/L accounts.
    • Price Control: Determines how the material is valuated.
      • 'S' (Standard Price): The material is always valuated at a fixed standard price for a given period. All inventory movements use this price. Any deviation is posted to a price difference account. This is mandatory for manufactured goods (semi-finished and finished).
      • 'V' (Moving Average Price - MAP): The price is automatically updated based on the total value of the material divided by the total quantity in stock. Typically used for procured raw materials.
  • Costing 1 & 2 Views:
    • Origin Group: An optional field that allows for further subdivision of material costs. For example, you can create origin groups like INTERCO (for materials from another company code) or EXTERN (for externally procured materials). This allows you to assign different overhead rates or see a more granular breakdown in the cost estimate. (Ref: FCD-CO0525)
    • Do Not Cost: A flag to exclude a material from costing runs.
    • With Quantity Structure: This must be checked for all materials that are manufactured in-house. It tells the system to use a Bill of Material (BOM) and Routing to calculate the cost.
    • Material Origin: When checked, it allows you to see the material number of a component as a separate line item in the cost estimate of the higher-level assembly, which is excellent for cost analysis.
    • Standard Price Fields: The Standard Price (current), Future Price (planned), Previous Price, and Last Price fields are displayed here. The costing run first calculates a future price, which is then formally "released" to become the current standard price.

Chapter 4: Production Master Data - The Recipe for Costing

For manufactured goods, the system needs to know what components are used and what activities are performed. This is defined in the production master data.

  • Bill of Material (BOM) (Fiori App: Maintain Bill of Material - CS01/CS02/CS03): A structured list of all the components and their quantities required to produce a finished or semi-finished good. It provides the "material" input for the cost estimate.
  • Work Center (Fiori App: Manage Work Center - CR01/CR02/CR03): Represents a machine, a group of machines, or a person/group of people where production operations are performed.
    • Costing Tab: This is the critical integration point. You assign a Cost Center to the work center. You also define the Activity Types (e.g., Machine Hours, Labor Hours) performed at this work center and the Formulas used to calculate how many hours are required per operation.
  • Routing (Fiori App: Manage Routings - CA01/CA02/CA03): A sequence of operations that must be performed to manufacture a product. Each operation is assigned to a Work Center. The routing specifies the standard time (e.g., setup time, machine time, labor time) required for each activity type to produce a certain quantity. This provides the "activity" input for the cost estimate.

End-to-End Flow Example: When a cost estimate is run for Finished Good FG-100:

  1. The system finds the Routing for FG-100.
  2. It reads the operations and the standard time values (e.g., 0.5 hours of machine time).
  3. It looks at the Work Center for that operation to find the assigned Cost Center (e.g., CC-PROD100) and Activity Type (e.g., MACH_HR).
  4. It looks at the Activity Type/Cost Center plan to find the planned rate (e.g., $50 / hour).
  5. It calculates the activity cost: 0.5 hours * $50/hour = $25. This becomes the "Labor" or "Overhead" portion of the cost.

Part II: Configuring the Costing Engine

This is the "brain" of product costing, where you define the rules for how costs are calculated, structured, and valuated.

(Customizing Path: SPRO -> Controlling -> Product Cost Controlling)

Chapter 5: The Cost Component Structure (CCS)

The Cost Component Structure is one of the most important configuration objects. It breaks down the cost of a product into meaningful groups, such as Raw Materials, Packaging, Direct Labor, Machine Overhead, etc. This structure is used for analysis and for updating different G/L accounts. (Ref: FCD-CO0540)

  • Purpose:
    • Provides a detailed, structured view of a product's cost.
    • Defines which costs are considered "cost of goods manufactured" vs. "cost of goods sold."
    • Controls how costs are rolled up through multi-level production processes.
  • Configuration (OKTZ):
    1. Define Cost Components: You create codes and descriptions (e.g., 10 - Raw Materials, 20 - Packaging, 80 - Direct Labor, 100 - Machine Overhead).
    2. Assign G/L Accounts to Cost Components: For material costs, you assign the material consumption G/L accounts to the relevant cost components. You can use the Origin Group from the material master for more detailed assignments. For example:
      • G/L Account 400000 (Raw Mat Consumption) -> Cost Component 10
      • G/L Account 400000 + Origin Group INTERCO -> Cost Component 15 (Intercompany Materials)
    3. Assign Secondary Cost Elements to Cost Components: For activity costs and overhead, you assign the secondary cost elements for activity allocation to cost components. For example:
      • Secondary G/L 943000 (Activity Allocation) + Activity Type LAB_HR -> Cost Component 80 (Direct Labor)
      • Secondary G/L 943000 + Activity Type MACH_HR -> Cost Component 100 (Machine Overhead)
    4. Create Cost Component Structure: You group the cost components into a named structure (e.g., S1 - Main Structure) and define attributes for each component, such as whether it's part of the "Cost of Goods Manufactured" and whether the cost is rolled up to the next level.

Chapter 6: Overhead Costing (Costing Sheets)

Many manufacturing costs are indirect (overhead) and cannot be directly assigned to a product, such as factory supervision, maintenance, or utilities. The Costing Sheet is a tool to allocate these costs to products based on a predefined basis. (Ref: FCD-CO0530)

  • Structure of a Costing Sheet (KZS2):
    • Base: Defines what costs the overhead will be applied to. This is typically a group of cost components (e.g., Total Material Costs or Total Labor Costs).
    • Overhead Rate: The percentage or quantity-based rate to be applied. This is defined per Controlling Area, Plant, and an optional "Overhead Key" for more granularity.
    • Credit: Defines the Cost Center and secondary G/L account that will be credited when the overhead is applied to the production order. This ensures the cost is moved from the overhead cost center to the product.
  • Example Scenario:
    • Business Rule: Apply a 15% Manufacturing Overhead on all material costs.
    • Configuration:
      1. Base: Create a base B001 that includes cost components 10 (Raw Materials) and 20 (Packaging).
      2. Overhead Rate: Create a percentage-based rate OVH1. In transaction KZM2, define that for Plant 1010, the rate OVH1 is 15%.
      3. Credit: Define a credit C001 that credits Cost Center CC-PROD_OVHD via secondary G/L 941000.
      4. Costing Sheet: Combine these in a row: Base B001 -> Overhead Rate OVH1 -> Credit C001.

When the cost estimate is run, if a product has $100 of material costs, the system will automatically calculate and add $15 of manufacturing overhead.

Chapter 7: The Costing Variant - The Central Control Key

The Costing Variant is the container that holds all the parameters for a specific costing purpose. You will have different costing variants for different needs (e.g., standard cost estimate, current cost estimate, inventory costing). (Ref: FCD-CO0630)

(Configuration: OKKN) A costing variant is defined by combining four key components:

  1. Costing Type:
    • Determines the purpose of the costing (e.g., 01 for standard price update).
    • Controls which price field in the material master is updated (Standard price, Tax price, etc.).
    • Defines if and how partner cost component splits are handled in intercompany scenarios.
  2. Valuation Variant: This is the most important part. It specifies in detail which prices the system should use to value the materials and activities.
    • Material Valuation: Defines the priority sequence for selecting a material price. A common strategy is:
      1. Planned Price 1 from the Material Master.
      2. Standard Price.
      3. Moving Average Price.
    • Activity Valuation: Defines how to value internal activities. The standard method is to use the "Plan price for the period."
    • Subcontracting: Defines how to value subcontracting services, usually from purchasing info records.
    • Overhead: Links to the Costing Sheet to be used.
  3. Date Control:
    • Defines the default dates for the costing run (e.g., costing from, costing to, quantity structure date).
    • This is critical because it determines which BOM/Routing versions and which material/activity prices are valid on the day of the calculation.
  4. Quantity Structure Control:
    • Defines how the system finds a valid BOM and Routing for the material being costed.
    • You specify the BOM Application and Routing Selection ID.

Generalizing the "Z" Variants: The custom variants (ZPC1, ZPC2, ZPC3) from the source document represent a common business need:

  • ZPC1 Rollup fin d’année: This translates to a "Year-End Standard Cost" variant used for the annual revaluation of all materials. Its key feature is that it performs a full recalculation from scratch, ignoring any existing cost estimates to ensure all new prices and production structures are captured.
  • ZPC2 Nx art. VALOIS Ecrs dex.: This translates to a "New Product Costing - Current Year" variant. It's used for costing new products introduced during the year. Its key feature is that it should transfer existing cost estimates for components that are already costed. This improves performance and ensures consistency. This is controlled by the "Transfer Control" setting within the Costing Variant.

Part III: The Standard Costing Process - Planning

With the foundation and configuration in place, you can now execute the standard costing process. The goal is to calculate the standard price for all manufactured goods for the upcoming period (usually a year).

Chapter 8: Creating the Standard Cost Estimate (The Costing Run)

The Costing Run is a powerful tool that allows you to cost a large number of materials in a structured, multi-step process.

(Fiori App: Manage Costing Runs - F2017 / SAP GUI: CK40N)

The process consists of the following steps, which you execute in sequence within the run:

  1. Selection: You define the set of materials to be costed (e.g., all finished goods in a specific plant). The system will automatically include all lower-level semi-finished goods and components.
  2. Structure Explosion: The system reads the BOMs and Routings for all selected materials to determine the full quantity structure.
  3. Costing: The core step. The system works from the lowest level of the BOM upwards (raw materials first, then semi-finished, then finished). It calculates the cost for each material based on the rules defined in the Costing Variant.
  4. Analysis: Before updating any prices, you must analyze the results. The system provides detailed reports showing the calculated prices, comparing them to previous prices, and highlighting any errors (e.g., missing master data, missing prices for components).
  5. Marking: This step authorizes the calculated prices to be updated. The price is saved as the "Future Planned Price" in the material master's costing view. Marking is a prerequisite for release and can only be done once per company code per period.
  6. Release: This is the final step that makes the new cost legally valid. The system copies the "Future Planned Price" into the "Current Standard Price" field. This action also generates a financial accounting document to revalue the existing inventory to the new standard price.

Chapter 9: Analyzing the Cost Estimate

Thorough analysis is crucial before releasing a new standard cost.

(Fiori App: Display Material Cost Estimates - CK13N)

When you display a cost estimate, you can see:

  • The total cost, broken down by the Cost Component Structure.
  • An "Itemization" view, which shows every single material and activity that went into the cost, line by line.
  • The lot size used for the calculation.
  • The master data (BOM/Routing) that was used.

Part IV: The Actual Costing Process - Execution & Period-End Close

While standard costing is about planning, the actual costing process tracks costs as they happen during production and then analyzes the differences at the end of the month.

Chapter 10: Production Order Costing

A production order (or process order) is the central cost object for discrete and process manufacturing. As production activities occur, costs are automatically posted to the order in real-time.

(Fiori App: Manage Production Orders - F2343 / CO03)

  • Planned Costs: When a production order is created, the system calculates planned costs based on the current BOM/Routing and standard prices.
  • Actual Costs:
    • Goods Issue: When raw materials are issued to the order, their value (at standard price or MAP) is debited to the order.
    • Activity Confirmations: When workers confirm that they have completed an operation (e.g., entering hours worked), the system debits the order with the actual activity quantity multiplied by the planned activity rate.
    • Overhead Application: At month-end (or in real-time with certain settings), the costing sheet is applied to the order to debit it with overhead costs.
    • Goods Receipt: When the finished product is received from the order into inventory, the order is credited with the quantity received multiplied by the product's standard price.

At any point, the balance of the production order is the difference between total debits and total credits.

Chapter 11: Period-End Closing for Manufacturing

At the end of each month, a series of steps must be performed for all production orders to ensure costs are correctly accounted for. This is a critical process for the finance and controlling teams.

(Fiori Cockpit: Financial Closing Cockpit)

11.1: Actual Overhead Calculation (KGI2 / CO43)

This step applies the overhead from the costing sheet to all production orders that have incurred costs during the period. This debits the order and credits the overhead cost center.

11.2: Work in Process (WIP) Calculation (KKAX / KKAO)

For any production orders that are not yet fully delivered, the order will have a balance (debits > credits). This balance represents the value of the unfinished goods. The WIP calculation determines this value. (Ref: FCD-CO0740)

  • Concept: WIP is calculated at actual costs. The result is an asset on the balance sheet ("Work in Process Inventory").
  • Process: The system calculates the WIP value for each order. When settlement is run, it generates a financial posting:
    • Debit: WIP Inventory (Balance Sheet Account)
    • Credit: WIP Offset / Change (P&L Account)
  • Important: In the following month, this posting is automatically reversed. When the order is finally finished, the WIP is cancelled, and any remaining balance is treated as a variance. The documents correctly state that at "Valois," this FI posting was not activated, meaning WIP was only a statistical value in CO. However, best practice is to post it to FI for accurate financial statements.

11.3: Variance Calculation (KKS2 / KKS1)

For production orders that are fully delivered or technically complete, any remaining balance on the order is a variance. This is the difference between the actual costs incurred and the value credited to the order (which was based on the standard price). (Ref: FCD-CO0750)

  • Process: The variance calculation step analyzes the order balance and breaks it down into different categories, providing valuable insights into production performance.
  • Common Variance Categories:
    • Input Price Variance: The actual price paid for a material was different from its standard price.
    • Input Quantity Variance: More or less material was consumed than planned in the BOM.
    • Resource-Usage Variance: More or less activity (e.g., labor hours) was used than planned in the routing.
    • Lot-Size Variance: Fixed costs (like setup) are spread over a different production quantity than planned.

11.4: Production Order Settlement (CO88 / KO88)

Settlement is the final step that moves the costs off the production order to their final destinations. (Ref: FCD-CO0760)

  • Process: The settlement run processes each order.
    • For incomplete orders, it settles the WIP value to FI.
    • For completed orders, it settles the variances to FI and, crucially, to Profitability Analysis (CO-PA).
  • Financial Posting (Variances):
    • Debit/Credit: Production Variance Accounts (P&L)
    • Debit/Credit: The Production Order is credited/debited to bring its balance to zero.
  • CO-PA Posting: The variances are transferred to CO-PA, where they can be analyzed by product, customer, etc. This enriches profitability reporting by showing not just standard profit but also the impact of manufacturing inefficiencies. The documents note that "Valois" did not settle variances to CO-PA, but this is a core functionality and best practice in S/4HANA.

Part V: Advanced Topics & Integration

Product costing extends beyond simple in-house manufacturing. Here's how to handle more complex, real-world scenarios.

Chapter 12: Handling Complex Scenarios

(Ref: FCD-CO0610, FCD-CO0620)

  • Subcontracting:
    • Assembly/Article Subcontracting: The process where you provide components to a vendor who performs an assembly service. In the cost estimate, the system values your components and adds the subcontracting service cost from a Purchasing Info Record.
    • Operation Subcontracting: A single operation in your internal routing is performed by an external vendor. The system values this operation based on the price in the Purchasing Info Record.
  • Intercompany / Inter-Plant Transfers: When a product is manufactured in Plant A and transferred to Plant B, Plant B needs to know its cost. Using a "Special Procurement Key" in the material master at Plant B, the cost estimate can be configured to find and transfer the existing cost estimate from Plant A. This ensures a consistent, rolled-up cost across the enterprise.
  • Mixed Costing (Make vs. Buy): Businesses often have multiple ways to procure the same material (e.g., 70% in-house production, 30% purchased from an external vendor). To get a standard price that reflects this mix, you use Mixed Costing.
    • You create different "Procurement Alternatives" (one for the internal routing, one for the purchasing process).
    • You then define a "Mixing Ratio" (e.g., 70/30).
    • When the cost estimate runs, it calculates the cost for each alternative and then computes a weighted-average standard price. This is the standard S/4HANA solution for the "CO Routings" described in the source documents.

Chapter 13: Full Cost vs. Standard Cost

(Ref: FCD-CO0520)

The source documents distinguish between a "PRU" (standard cost for inventory) and a "PRC" (full cost including non-manufacturing costs like Selling, G&A, and R&D). This is a common management accounting requirement.

  • Standard Cost (for Inventory): This is the official standard price stored in the material master. It must only include production-related costs, as per accounting principles. This is calculated using the primary costing variant.
  • Full Cost (for Profitability/Pricing): This includes the standard cost plus an allocation of Selling, General & Administrative (SG&A) costs. This cost should never be used for inventory valuation.
  • Solution in S/4HANA: The best-practice method is not to create a separate "full cost" estimate that updates a price field. Instead:
    1. Calculate the official Standard Cost as usual. This value becomes the Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) in Profitability Analysis (CO-PA).
    2. In CO-PA, use the CO-PA Valuation functionality to apply SG&A costs statistically. This is done by creating a costing sheet in CO-PA that applies a percentage surcharge to the COGS to calculate the "Full Cost of Sales" for reporting purposes.
    3. This keeps the legal inventory valuation clean while providing enriched management reporting data in CO-PA.

Chapter 14: Integration with Other Modules

Product Costing is not an island. The standard cost it produces is used throughout the SAP S/4HANA system.

  • MM & EWM (Inventory Management): Every goods movement (receipt, issue, transfer) for a material with standard price control is valuated at that standard price.
  • SD (Sales & Distribution): When a delivery is posted for a sales order, the system creates a financial document that debits Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) with the standard price of the material sold.
  • FI (Finance): All inventory valuation, WIP, variance, and COGS postings are made to the General Ledger in real-time via the Universal Journal (ACDOCA).
  • CO-PA (Profitability Analysis): The standard cost (COGS) and production variances are key inputs for calculating product and customer profitability.

Part VI: The Integrated Test Plan

This test plan provides a series of end-to-end scenarios to practice the concepts covered in the guide. It follows a logical business flow, from master data creation to final financial closing.

Test Scenario 1: Master Data Setup

  • Objective: Create all necessary master data for a new finished product, including its components.
  • Prerequisites: Organizational structure (Company Code, Plant, etc.) exists. G/L accounts are configured.
  • Step-by-Step Instructions:
    1. Create Raw Material (MM01):
      • Material: RM-T100 (e.g., Plastic Resin)
      • Views: Basic Data, Purchasing, Accounting 1 (Price control 'V', enter a moving average price), Costing 1 & 2.
    2. Create Semi-Finished Good (MM01):
      • Material: SFG-T100 (e.g., Molded Casing)
      • Views: Basic Data, MRP 1-4, Work Scheduling, Accounting 1 (Price control 'S'), Costing 1 & 2 (check 'With Qty Structure').
    3. Create Finished Good (MM01):
      • Material: FG-T100 (e.g., Assembled Device)
      • Views: Same as Semi-Finished, plus Sales views.
    4. Create Work Centers (CR01):
      • Work Center 1: WC-MOULD (Molding Machine). In the Costing tab, assign a cost center and create an activity type MACH_HR (Machine Hours).
      • Work Center 2: WC-ASSY (Assembly Line). In the Costing tab, assign a cost center and create an activity type LAB_HR (Labor Hours).
    5. Plan Activity Rates (KP26): For the cost center/activity type combinations above, enter a planned price (e.g., $50/hr for MACH_HR, $40/hr for LAB_HR).
    6. Create BOMs (CS01):
      • BOM for SFG-T100: Component RM-T100, Qty 1 EA.
      • BOM for FG-T100: Component SFG-T100, Qty 1 EA.
    7. Create Routings (CA01):
      • Routing for SFG-T100: One operation using WC-MOULD, with 0.5 hours of machine time.
      • Routing for FG-T100: One operation using WC-ASSY, with 0.25 hours of labor time.
  • Expected Results: All master data objects are created without error. The links between work centers, cost centers, and activity types are correctly established.

Test Scenario 2: Standard Cost Estimate Execution

  • Objective: Calculate and release the standard price for the new finished good FG-T100.
  • Prerequisites: Test Scenario 1 is complete. Costing Variant is configured.
  • Step-by-Step Instructions:
    1. Create Costing Run (CK40N / F2017): Create a new run for the current period.
    2. Selection: Enter FG-T100 in your plant.
    3. Structure Explosion: Execute. Check the log for errors.
    4. Costing: Execute. Check the log for errors.
    5. Analysis: Analyze the cost estimate for FG-T100. Use CK13N to view the cost component split. You should see costs for RM-T100, machine hours for SFG-T100, and labor hours for FG-T100.
    6. Marking: Execute.
    7. Release: Execute.
  • Expected Results:
    • The cost estimate for FG-T100 is calculated successfully.
    • The Future Price field in the material masters (FG-T100, SFG-T100) is populated after marking.
    • The Standard Price field is updated after release. An accounting document is generated if there was existing stock.

Test Scenario 3: Procure-to-Pay for a Component

  • Objective: Purchase the raw material to see how inventory is valuated.
  • Prerequisites: RM-T100 exists with MAP.
  • Step-by-Step Instructions:
    1. Create Purchase Order (ME21N): Create a PO for 100 units of RM-T100 from a vendor.
    2. Post Goods Receipt (MIGO): Receive the 100 units against the PO.
  • Expected Results:
    • An accounting document is posted: Debit Raw Material Inventory, Credit GR/IR Clearing.
    • The Moving Average Price of RM-T100 is updated in the material master.

Test Scenario 4: Plan-to-Produce End-to-End

  • Objective: Create and process a production order for the finished good to see how actual costs are collected.
  • Prerequisites: Standard cost for FG-T100 and SFG-T100 exists. Stock of RM-T100 is available.
  • Step-by-Step Instructions:
    1. Create Production Order (CO01): Create an order to produce 10 units of FG-T100. Release the order.
    2. (Optional - for SFG): First, create and process an order for 10 units of SFG-T100 to put it in stock.
    3. Issue Goods to Order (MIGO): Issue 10 units of SFG-T100 to the production order for FG-T100.
    4. Confirm Production Activities (CO11N): Confirm the assembly operation, entering the actual labor hours used.
    5. Receive Goods from Order (MIGO): Post a goods receipt for 10 units of the finished FG-T100 from the production order.
    6. Analyze Order Costs (KKBC_ORD / F3332): Display the production order and view the cost report. Compare planned vs. actual costs.
  • Expected Results:
    • Actual costs for materials and labor are debited to the production order.
    • The order is credited with the value of the 10 finished units at their standard price.
    • The order now has a balance, which represents the initial variance before month-end closing.

Test Scenario 5: Order-to-Cash

  • Objective: Sell the finished good to see the COGS posting.
  • Prerequisites: FG-T100 is in stock.
  • Step-by-Step Instructions:
    1. Create Sales Order (VA01): Create an order for 5 units of FG-T100 for a customer.
    2. Create Outbound Delivery (VL01N): Create a delivery for the sales order.
    3. Post Goods Issue (VL02N): Post the goods issue for the delivery.
    4. Create Invoice (VF01): Bill the customer for the delivery.
  • Expected Results:
    • When the goods issue is posted, a key accounting document is created:
      • Debit: Cost of Goods Sold (P&L Account)
      • Credit: Finished Goods Inventory (Balance Sheet Account)
    • The value of this posting is 5 units * Standard Price of FG-T100.
    • A profitability segment document is generated in CO-PA, showing revenue from the invoice and COGS from the goods issue.

Test Scenario 6: Period-End Close

  • Objective: Perform month-end closing steps for the production order from Scenario 4.
  • Prerequisites: The production order from Scenario 4 has been fully delivered and is technically complete (TECO status).
  • Step-by-Step Instructions:
    1. Calculate Overhead (KGI2): Run overhead calculation for the production order.
    2. Calculate WIP (KKAX): Run WIP calculation. Since the order is TECO, the WIP should be zero.
    3. Calculate Variances (KKS2): Run variance calculation for the order. The system will categorize the order balance into different variance types.
    4. Settle Order (CO88): Settle the production order.
  • Expected Results:
    • Overhead costs are posted to the order.
    • The order balance is categorized into variances (e.g., quantity variance if you used more/less SFG-T100 than planned).
    • After settlement, the order balance is zero.
    • An accounting document is posted to move the variances from the production cost center to P&L variance accounts.
    • The variances are also posted to CO-PA for profitability reporting.
