entry.title: The Ultimate Guide to Product Costing & WIP in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
What is Product Costing? 🤔

At its core, Product Costing is about answering a simple question: "How much does it cost us to produce a product?" It's the process of planning costs and then tracking the actual costs incurred during the manufacturing of a good. This involves calculating the cost of:

  • Raw Materials: The components that go into the final product.
  • Labor: The work done by employees to assemble or manufacture the product.
  • Overhead: All other indirect costs, like factory electricity, machine depreciation, and supervisor salaries.

By understanding these costs, a company can make informed decisions about product pricing, profitability analysis, and production efficiency.

Why is Work in Process (WIP) Important? 💡

Imagine you're building a bicycle. At the end of the month, you've attached the wheels and handlebars to the frame, but you haven't added the seat or pedals yet. The bicycle is not finished, so it's not yet inventory. However, you've spent money on the parts and the labor. This half-finished bicycle is Work in Process (WIP).

In accounting, the matching principle states that expenses should be recognized in the same period as the revenues they help to generate. Since a half-finished product hasn't generated any revenue, its costs shouldn't be treated as a full expense for the period (Cost of Goods Sold). Instead, these costs are temporarily capitalized on the balance sheet as a WIP asset.

When the product is finally finished in the next period, the WIP is reversed, and the full cost is moved to the finished goods inventory. This ensures accurate financial reporting each month.

The End-to-End Process Flow

The manufacturing and costing process in SAP follows a logical flow, from initial planning to final financial settlement.

  1. Planning & Master Data: You define all the ingredients, steps, and resources needed to make a product.
  2. Production Execution: A production order is created, and the actual manufacturing process begins. Materials are used, and labor is performed, which posts actual costs to the order.
  3. Period-End Closing: This is a crucial multi-step process performed at the end of each month.
    • Overhead Calculation: Indirect costs are allocated to the production order.
    • WIP Calculation: For any orders that are not yet finished, SAP calculates the value of the WIP.
    • Variance Calculation: Once an order is finished, SAP compares the planned costs to the actual costs to determine the variance.
    • Settlement: The calculated WIP or variances are posted to the General Ledger (FI) and Profitability Analysis (CO-PA).

Chapter 2: Master Data - The Foundation of Costing

Correct and complete master data is the bedrock of accurate product costing. If the foundation is weak, the entire structure will be unreliable.

Material Master

  • What it is: The central record for a material, containing all information related to its procurement, storage, production, and costing.
  • How to access it: SAP Fiori App "Manage Product Master Data" or SAP GUI T-code MM01/MM02/MM03.
  • Key Fields (Costing & Accounting Views):
    • Valuation Class: This is the critical link between the material and the General Ledger. It determines which inventory G/L account is updated when the material moves.
    • Price Control: Determines how the material is valued.
      • 'V' (Moving Average Price): The price is the total value divided by the total quantity in stock. Typically used for raw materials.
      • 'S' (Standard Price): The price is fixed for a period based on a standard cost estimate. Typically used for finished goods.
    • Standard/Moving Average Price: The actual valuation price of the material.
  • Example:
    • Raw Material (B-FRAME01 - Bicycle Frame): Price Control 'V', Valuation Class 3000 (Raw Materials).
    • Finished Good (B-BIKE01 - Racing Bicycle): Price Control 'S', Valuation Class 7920 (Finished Goods).

Bill of Material (BOM)

  • What it is: A structured list of all the components and their quantities required to produce one unit of a finished product. It's like a recipe.
  • How to access it: SAP Fiori App "Maintain Bill of Material" or SAP GUI T-code CS01/CS02/CS03.
  • Example: The BOM for one "Racing Bicycle" (B-BIKE01) might contain:
    • 1 pc B-FRAME01 (Frame)
    • 2 pc B-WHEEL01 (Wheel)
    • 1 pc B-SADDLE01 (Saddle)

Work Center

  • What it is: A specific location in the plant where production operations are performed. It can be a machine, a group of machines, or an assembly line.
  • How to access it: SAP Fiori App "Manage Work Center" or SAP GUI T-code CR01/CR02/CR03.
  • Key Fields (Costing Tab):
    • Cost Center: The work center is linked to a cost center, which is responsible for collecting the costs incurred at that location.
    • Activity Types: These represent the activities performed at the work center, like "Machine Hours" or "Labor Hours".

Routing

  • What it is: A sequence of operations required to manufacture a product. It specifies which work center is used for each step and how much time (e.g., machine time, labor time) is required.
  • How to access it: SAP Fiori App "Manage Routings" or SAP GUI T-code CA01/CA02/CA03.
  • Example: The routing for the "Racing Bicycle" might have one operation:
    • Operation 0010: Assemble Bicycle, performed at the "ASSEMBLY" work center, requiring 1 hour of labor.

Activity Types & Prices

  • What they are: Activity Types classify the activities performed within a cost center (e.g., L-LABORHR for Labor Hours). An Activity Price is the planned rate for that activity (e.g., $50 per labor hour).
  • How to access them:
    • Create Activity Type: KL01.
    • Plan Activity Price: Fiori App "Manage Activity Type Plan Rates" or KP26.
  • How it works: When you confirm work was done on a production order, the system multiplies the confirmed hours (from the routing) by the planned activity price to calculate the actual labor/machine cost.

Chapter 3: The Core Process - From Production Order to Financial Posting

This chapter walks you through the life cycle of a production order, showing how costs are accumulated and how WIP is ultimately calculated and posted.

Step 1: Create a Production Order

A production order is the official request to the shop floor to produce a certain quantity of a product by a specific date.

  • How-To: Use the Fiori App "Create Production Order" (or SAP GUI CO01).
  • Process: When you create an order for our "Racing Bicycle," the system automatically copies the BOM and Routing. This calculates the planned costs for the order based on the standard price of the components and the planned activity rates. The Order Type is crucial, as it contains default parameters, including the one that tells the system to calculate WIP for this order.

Step 2: Goods Issue to Production Order

The shop floor withdraws the necessary raw materials from the warehouse to begin production.

  • How-To: Use the Fiori App "Post Goods Movement" (or SAP GUI MIGO). Use movement type 261.
  • Process: Issuing the frames and wheels to the order posts the cost of those materials to the order as an actual cost.
  • Financial Impact:
    • Debit: Material Consumption Expense (a P&L account)
    • Credit: Raw Material Inventory (a Balance Sheet account)

Step 3: Confirm Production Activities

Workers confirm the time they spent on each operation.

  • How-To: Use the Fiori App "Confirm Production Operation" (or SAP GUI CO11N).
  • Process: Confirming 1 hour of assembly work posts the labor cost to the order as an actual cost (1 hour x $50/hour = $50).
  • Financial Impact: This is an internal CO posting. It debits the production order and credits the assembly cost center.

Step 4: Goods Receipt from Production Order

Finished products are completed and moved from the shop floor into the finished goods warehouse.

  • How-To: Use the Fiori App "Post Goods Movement" (or SAP GUI MIGO). Use movement type 101.
  • Process: If the order was for 10 bikes and 5 are now complete, you post a goods receipt for 5 units. The production order is credited with the value of these 5 bikes (5 x Standard Price).
  • Financial Impact:
    • Debit: Finished Goods Inventory (a Balance Sheet account)
    • Credit: Production Output / Change in Stock (a P&L account)

Step 5: Period-End Closing - The Main Event

At the end of the month, the order has actual debits (materials, labor) and an actual credit (for the 5 completed bikes). Since it's not fully delivered, it has WIP. This is where the period-end process comes in.

  • A. (Optional) Overhead Calculation: Use Fiori App "Run Overhead Calculation - Production" (or KGI2) to apply overhead costs (e.g., electricity) to the order.
  • B. WIP Calculation: This is the key step.
    • How-To: Use Fiori App "Run WIP Calculation" (or KKAX for single orders, KKAO for multiple).
    • What happens? The system uses the configuration (detailed in Chapter 4) to calculate the WIP value. In its simplest form: WIP = Total Actual Debits - Total Actual Credits. The system calculates this value but does not post it to FI yet. The order gets the status RESA (Results Analysis carried out).
  • C. Settlement: This step takes the calculated WIP amount and posts it to the General Ledger.
    • How-To: Use Fiori App "Run Settlement - Actual" (or CO88).
    • What happens? The system generates a financial accounting document.
    • Financial Impact:
      • Debit: WIP Inventory (a Balance Sheet account)
      • Credit: Change in WIP (a P&L account, offsetting the material consumption expenses)

At the start of the next period, this posting is automatically reversed. If the order is completed in the next period, the final settlement will clear the remaining balance to variance accounts instead of WIP.

Chapter 4: Deep Dive - Configuring WIP Calculation

This chapter is for key users and consultants. It translates the provided technical documents into a step-by-step guide on how to configure WIP in the system using the SAP Implementation Guide (IMG).

SPRO Path: Controlling > Product Cost Controlling > Cost Object Controlling > Product Cost by Order > Period-End Closing > Work in Process

4.1. Define Results Analysis Keys (RA Keys)

  • Concept: The RA Key is a simple code (e.g., Z001) that you assign to a production order type. If an order has an RA Key, the system knows it is a candidate for WIP calculation. This is the primary trigger. 111
  • Customizing: ... > Work in Process > Define Results Analysis Keys. Simply create a new key.

4.2. Define Results Analysis Versions

  • Concept: The RA Version (always version 0 for actual costs) is the master control object that holds the parameters for how WIP and variances are calculated. 222222222
  • Customizing: ... > Work in Process > Define Results Analysis Versions.
  • Key Parameters:
    • Transfer to Financial Accounting: This checkbox MUST be selected to post WIP to the General Ledger. 3
    • Separate Create/Settle: Allows you to use different G/L accounts for the initial creation of WIP and its subsequent reversal/consumption. 4

4.3. Define Valuation Methods

  • Concept: This links the RA Key to a valuation method, which tells the system how to calculate WIP based on the order's status. The standard method is

0 - Actual Costs. 5

  • Customizing: ... > Work in Process > Define Valuation Method (Actual Costs).
  • Process: Here, you assign a status code to a "WIP Method".
    • Status REL (Released): Calculate WIP. The order is active and incurring costs.
    • Status DLV (Delivered) / TECO (Technically Completed): Cancel WIP. The order is finished, so the WIP balance must be zeroed out, and the remaining balance is treated as a variance.

4.4. Define Line IDs

  • Concept: Line IDs are simple codes used to categorize and group costs on a production order. They are freely definable (e.g., MAT for materials, LAB for labor, OHD for overhead). This grouping is essential for deciding what to do with different types of costs. 6
  • Customizing: ... > Work in Process > Define Line IDs.

4.5. Define Assignment of Cost Elements

  • Concept: This is a critical step where you map cost elements (which are G/L accounts) to the Line IDs you just created. This tells the system, "When you see a cost from G/L account 400000 (Raw Material Consumption), categorize it under Line ID

MAT." 7

  • Customizing: ... > Work in Process > Define Assignment.
  • Key Columns:
    • Cost Element Mask: You can enter a specific G/L account or use a mask. For example,

4+++++ would capture all accounts starting with 4. 8

    • Line ID Columns (Capitalize, With Profit, Do Not Capitalize): For each mapping, you must assign the Line ID to one of these three columns:
      • Int. actif (Capitalize): Place Line IDs here for costs you want to include in your WIP asset value (e.g., MAT, LAB). 9
      • Int. poss. (Capitalize with Conditions/Percentage): Used for costs you want to partially capitalize. You specify the percentage to capitalize. 10101010
      • Non int. actif (Do Not Capitalize): Place Line IDs here for costs you want to expense immediately and exclude from WIP (e.g., certain overheads). 11

4.6. Define Update Rules

  • Concept: This step links your Line IDs to predefined SAP Categories. These categories are hard-coded and tell the system if a Line ID represents a cost or a receipt. 12
  • Customizing: ... > Work in Process > Define Update.
  • Key Categories:
    • K (Costs): You assign all your cost-related Line IDs (MAT, LAB, OHD) to this category. 13
    • A (Receipts): You assign the Line ID representing goods receipts (crediting the order) to this category. 14

4.7. Define Posting Rules for Settlement

  • Concept: This is the final and most important configuration step. It defines the exact G/L accounts that will be used for the financial posting during WIP settlement. It connects the results of the WIP calculation to the General Ledger. 15
  • Customizing: Financial Accounting > General Ledger Accounting > Periodic Processing > Integration > Materials Management > Define Account Determination for Materials Management. (The path may vary slightly, but it involves FI-MM integration settings, often under T-code OBYC for WIP, which points to the rules defined here). A more direct path is ... > Work in Process > Define Posting Rules for Settling Work in Process.
  • Process: You create rules for your Chart of Accounts. The rule maps a Results Analysis Category to a P&L account and a Balance Sheet account.
    • RA Categories are system-generated during WIP calculation based on your earlier setup. For example, costs you marked as "Capitalize" will fall into the RA Category

ECIA (WIP to be Capitalized). 16

  • Example Rule:
    • RA Category: ECIA (WIP Costs to be Capitalized)
    • P&L Account: 590000 (Change in WIP Inventory)
    • Balance Sheet Account: 150000 (WIP Inventory Asset)
    • Resulting Journal Entry: When you settle, the system will post Dr. 150000 and Cr. 590000. 17

4.8. Putting it all Together: Assignment to Order Type

  • Concept: The final piece of the puzzle is to assign the RA Key (from step 4.1) and other costing parameters to the specific Production Order Type you use for manufacturing.
  • Customizing: ... > Product Cost by Order > Manufacturing Orders > Define Default Values for Order Types 18
  • Action: For your production order type (e.g., PP01), you enter the default RA Key (e.g., Z001) in the "Results Analysis Key" field. 19 Now, every

PP01 order created will automatically be subject to WIP calculation.

Chapter 5: Integration with Other Logistics Modules

Product costing doesn't live in a bubble. Costs can flow from many different processes and modules, impacting the total WIP value.

  • Extended Warehouse Management (EWM):
    • Scenario: You use EWM to manage your warehouse. The process of picking components for a production order is complex and requires specific resources (labor, forklifts).
    • Integration: The costs for these warehouse activities can be collected in a cost center and allocated to production orders via overhead costing, increasing the total order cost and potential WIP.
  • Quality Management (QM):
    • Scenario: During production, an in-process inspection lot is created. The Quality Inspector finds a defect.
    • Integration: The costs associated with the inspection (inspector's time) and any resulting rework activities (which might be recorded via a separate rework order or additional confirmations on the original order) are posted to the production order. This increases the actual costs and, therefore, the WIP if the order is not yet complete. Costs of scrapped components also remain on the order, increasing WIP until settlement.
  • Transportation Management (TM) & Logistics Execution (LE):
    • Scenario: A critical component for your bicycle is imported, and you use TM to manage the freight costs.
    • Integration: These freight costs can be included in the inventory value of the component. When that component is issued to the production order, this higher material cost flows into the production order's actual costs, directly impacting the WIP calculation.
  • Plant Maintenance (PM) / Customer Service (CS):
    • Scenario: A machine on the assembly line, which is also a PM equipment record, breaks down during production. A maintenance order is created to repair it.
    • Integration: While the PM order costs are usually settled to the machine's cost center, in some scenarios (especially for major refurbishments), these costs could be allocated to production orders that were active during the downtime, adding to their overhead and WIP.
  • Handling Unit Management (HUM):
    • Scenario: You procure raw materials in specific handling units (e.g., pallets) that require special equipment to move.
    • Integration: The costs of managing these handling units (storage, movement) can be captured and applied as overhead to production orders, becoming part of the total manufacturing cost and WIP.

Part 2: Comprehensive End-to-End Test Plan

This test plan provides a realistic scenario to validate the entire WIP process flow, from master data creation to final financial postings.

Test Scenario: Manufacturing a high-end bicycle ("B-BIKE01") in Plant 1010.

Test Case 1: Master Data Setup & Cost Planning

Objective: Ensure all foundational data is correctly created and a standard cost for the product is established.

Step

Action

Transaction(s) / Fiori App

Expected Result

1

Create Raw Materials: B-FRAME01 (Frame), B-WHEEL01 (Wheel)

Manage Product Master Data / MM01

Materials created with Price Control 'V', appropriate valuation classes, and a moving average price (e.g., Frame=$150, Wheel=$40).

2

Create Finished Good: B-BIKE01 (Bicycle)

Manage Product Master Data / MM01

Material created with Price Control 'S', valuation class for finished goods. The standard price field is initially zero.

3

Create Bill of Material for B-BIKE01

Maintain Bill of Material / CS01

BOM created containing 1 B-FRAME01 and 2 B-WHEEL01.

4

Create Work Center ASSEMBLY

Manage Work Center / CR01

Work center created and linked to a cost center (e.g., PROD1000) and activity type L-LABORHR.

5

Create Routing for B-BIKE01

Manage Routings / CA01

Routing created with one operation at work center ASSEMBLY requiring 2 hours of labor.

6

Plan Activity Price

Manage Activity Type Plan Rates / KP26

A price of $50/hour is planned for activity L-LABORHR in cost center PROD1000.

7

Execute Standard Cost Estimate

Edit Cost Estimates / CK11N

A cost estimate for B-BIKE01 is calculated. Planned Cost = (1 x $150) + (2 x $40) + (2 hrs x $50/hr) = $150 + $80 + $100 = $330.

8

Mark & Release Cost Estimate

Manage Costing Runs / CK24

The planned cost of $330 is released. The standard price field for B-BIKE01 in the material master is now updated to $330.

Test Case 2: Production Execution (Generate Actual Costs)

Objective: Simulate the production process for an order of 10 bicycles and post actual costs. The period is Period 9.

Step

Action

Transaction(s) / Fiori App

Expected Result

1

Create Production Order for 10 B-BIKE01

Create Production Order / CO01

entry.title: The Ultimate SAP S/4HANA Guide for the Order-to-Cash Process
entry.content:
Introduction

Welcome to your end-to-end guide for navigating the sales process in SAP S/4HANA. Whether you're creating your first sales order, configuring the system, or testing a full business process, this document is for you. We will demystify core concepts, provide step-by-step instructions, and explain the "why" behind the "how."

Key Concepts in S/4HANA

  • SAP Fiori Launchpad: Your modern, role-based entry point to all applications. Instead of memorizing transaction codes, you'll use intuitive tiles to launch your tasks.
  • Business Role: Your Fiori Launchpad is tailored to your job. A Sales Representative sees different apps than a Warehouse Clerk or an Accounts Receivable Accountant.
  • Single Source of Truth: S/4HANA's in-memory database provides real-time insights. The data you see in sales is the same data seen in finance and logistics, instantly.

Chapter 1: The Foundation - Master Data

Before any transaction can occur, the system needs to know the "who," "what," and "how." This is the role of master data. It's the static data that is used repeatedly in your business transactions.

1.1. Business Partner (Customer)

In S/4HANA, the classic "Customer Master" is replaced by the Business Partner (BP). A single BP can have multiple roles, such as Customer, Supplier, or Contact Person.

How-To: Create a Customer

  1. App: Open the Manage Business Partner Master Data Fiori app.
  2. Click Create -> Organization.
  3. BP Role: Select FLCU00 - FI Customer to create the financial accounting data. Enter company code, reconciliation account, and payment terms.
  4. Click Save. The system will assign a BP number.
  5. Extend the BP: Re-open the BP you just created. Click Edit. In the "Create in Role" dropdown, select FLCU01 - Customer to add the sales-specific data.
  6. Go to the Sales and Distribution tab. Here you will enter the Sales Organization, Distribution Channel, Division (the Sales Area), as well as key data like Shipping Conditions, Delivery Priority, and Billing information.
  7. Click Save.

1.2. Product (Material Master)

The Product Master (or Material Master) contains all information about a product or service that your company buys, produces, sells, or stores.

How-To: Create a Finished Product

  1. App: Use the Manage Product Master Data Fiori app.
  2. Click Create.
  3. Enter a Product Number (or leave blank for internal numbering), Product Type (e.g., FERT for Finished Good), and a Base Unit of Measure (e.g., EA for Each).
  4. Views: The Product Master is organized into views. For a sellable product, you'll need to create at least the following:
    • Basic Data: Description, unit of measure, dimensions.
    • Sales: The delivering plant, tax classifications, and sales unit.
    • MRP 1-4: Data for production planning, such as MRP Type (e.g., PD for MRP) and Availability Check group. This is crucial for determining product availability during a sales order.
    • General Plant Data / Storage: Storage conditions and handling information.
    • Accounting: Valuation Class (which drives G/L account determination) and the price (standard or moving average).
  5. Populate the required fields in each view and click Save.

1.3. Pricing Condition Records

This master data determines the price of a product for a customer. It's the foundation of your pricing strategy.

How-To: Set a Product Price

  1. App: Use the Manage Prices - Sales Fiori app.
  2. Select a Condition Type, such as PR00 for a basic price or K007 for a customer-specific discount.
  3. Enter the Sales Organization and Distribution Channel.
  4. In the table, enter the Product, the Amount (e.g., 100 EUR), and the Unit (e.g., 1 EA).
  5. Set the Validity Period for which this price is active.
  6. Click Save.

Chapter 2: The Sales Order - Heart of the Process

The sales order is the central document in the sales process. It's a contractual agreement between your company and a customer to deliver products or services. Here, we'll see how various configuration elements come together to control the document's behavior.

2.1. Creating a Sales Order

The primary Fiori app for this is a modern equivalent of the classic VA01 transaction.

How-To: Create a Standard Sales Order

  1. App: Open the Create Sales Orders Fiori app.
  2. Order Type: Enter the order type, for example, OR for a Standard Order.
  3. Organizational Data: Enter the Sales Organization, Distribution Channel, and Division.
  4. Header Data:
    • Enter the Sold-To Party (the customer number). The system will automatically populate related partners like the Ship-To Party.
    • Enter a Customer Reference number (their PO number).
  5. Item Data:
    • In the "Items" table, enter the Product number and the Order Quantity.
    • Press Enter. The system will perform a series of background actions: pricing, availability check, text determination, etc.
  6. Review the details, check the confirmed quantities and dates, and click Save.

2.2. Understanding the "Why": Order Reasons

Concept: An Order Reason is a code that explains why a customer placed an order. This is invaluable for sales analysis and reporting. Was it a result of a marketing campaign? A replacement for a damaged shipment? This information helps you understand your business drivers.

When you create a sales order, you can assign an order reason at the header level, which then applies to all items.

Examples of Standard Order Reasons:

  • 001: Poor quality
  • 002: Transport damage
  • 006: Machine trials
  • 008: Other

How-To: Assign an Order Reason

In the Create Sales Orders app, go to the Sales tab at the header level. You will find the Order Reason field. Use the dropdown to select the appropriate reason.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing Order Reasons

You can define your own Order Reasons to match your business needs.

  • SAP GUI: Transaction OVAU
  • SPRO/CBC Path: Sales and Distribution -> Sales -> Sales Documents -> Sales Document Header -> Define Order Reasons

2.3. Controlling Line Items: Item Categories

Concept: The Item Category is one of the most powerful control elements in SD. It is automatically determined by the system based on the Sales Document Type and the material master, and it dictates the behavior of a line item in a sales document.

Key Questions the Item Category Answers:

  • Is this item relevant for pricing? (e.g., a standard item is, but a free-of-charge item is not).
  • Is this item relevant for delivery? (e.g., a standard product is, but a text item is not).
  • Is this item relevant for billing? (e.g., a standard item is, but a free sample might not be).
  • Does this item consume stock?
  • Should a schedule line be created for this item?

Common Standard Item Categories:

  • TAN: Standard Item. Relevant for pricing, delivery, and billing.
  • TANN: Free of Charge Item. Not relevant for pricing, but is relevant for delivery.
  • TATX: Text Item. Not relevant for pricing, delivery, or billing. Used for adding notes.
  • TAD: Service Item. Relevant for pricing and billing, but not for delivery as there is no physical product movement.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing Item Categories

Item categories are highly configurable to support a wide variety of business scenarios.

  • SAP GUI: Transaction VOV7
  • SPRO/CBC Path: Sales and Distribution -> Sales -> Sales Documents -> Sales Document Item -> Define Item Categories
  • Assignment: The system determines the item category using an assignment table. You can view this in transaction VOV4. The path is ... -> Sales Document Item -> Assign Item Categories.

2.4. Ensuring Data Quality: Incompletion Procedures

Concept: An Incompletion Procedure acts as a data quality checklist for your sales documents. You can define critical fields that must be filled in before a document can proceed to the next step in the process. If a mandatory field is missing, the system flags the document as "incomplete" and can block subsequent functions like delivery or billing.

For example, you can configure the system to prevent delivery creation if the customer's PO number is missing from the sales order.

How it Works:

  1. Status Group: First, you define a Status Group which specifies what functions are blocked. For example, a status group might block "Delivery Creation" or "Billing Document Creation."
  2. Incompletion Procedure: Next, you create a procedure where you list the mandatory fields (e.g., table VBAK, field AUGRU for Order Reason).
  3. Assign Status Group: For each field in your procedure, you assign a Status Group. This tells the system what to block if that specific field is empty.
  4. Assign Procedure: Finally, you assign the entire incompletion procedure to a Sales Document Type (for header fields) or an Item Category (for item fields).

Example in Action:

A user creates a sales order but forgets to enter the Payment Terms (VBKD-ZTERM).

  • The Incompletion Procedure assigned to the sales order type contains this field.
  • The procedure is configured to block Billing if this field is empty.
  • When the user saves, a pop-up appears listing the missing data.
  • The user can save the incomplete document, but when someone later tries to create an invoice, the system will issue an error message stating the sales order is incomplete.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing Incompletion

This is a multi-step configuration process that offers powerful control.

  1. Define Status Groups: SAP GUI OVA0. Path: ... -> Basic Functions -> Log of Incomplete Items -> Define Status Groups.
  2. Define Incompletion Procedures: SAP GUI OVA2. Path: ... -> Basic Functions -> Log of Incomplete Items -> Define Incompletion Procedures. Here you will add the tables, field names, and assign the status groups.
  3. Assign to Document Types/Item Categories: Path: ... -> Assign Incompletion Procedures to the Sales Document Types.

Note: The custom schemas Z1, Z2, ZG, ZN from the source documents would be implemented as new entries in these standard configuration tables.

2.5. Rejecting Unwanted Items: Rejection Reasons

Concept: A customer may decide not to proceed with a specific item in their order after it has been created. Instead of deleting the line, the best practice is to assign a Rejection Reason.

Why Reject instead of Delete?

  • Traceability: It maintains a record of what was originally requested and why it was cancelled.
  • Reporting: You can run reports to analyze why items are being rejected (e.g., "Too Expensive," "Long Delivery Time"). This provides valuable feedback to your sales, product, and logistics teams.
  • System Impact: Assigning a rejection reason automatically nullifies the item. It is no longer considered in MRP (demand planning) and cannot be delivered or billed.

Common Rejection Reasons:

  • 01: Delivery date too long
  • 02: Poor quality
  • 03: Too expensive
  • 04: Competitor has better service

How-To: Reject a Line Item

  1. In the Change Sales Orders (VA02) app, navigate to the line item you wish to reject.
  2. Go to the Reason for Rejection tab.
  3. Select an appropriate reason from the dropdown list.
  4. Click Save. The item will be updated and will no longer be active.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing Rejection Reasons

You can create reasons that are specific to your industry or business.

  • SAP GUI: Transaction OVAG
  • SPRO/CBC Path: Sales and Distribution -> Sales -> Sales Documents -> Sales Document Item -> Define Reasons For Rejection

Chapter 3: Availability Check and Delivery Scheduling

Once a sales order is entered, the system must answer two critical questions:

  1. Can we fulfill this order? (Availability Check)
  2. When can the customer expect it? (Delivery Scheduling)

3.1. The Availability Check (ATP)

Concept: The Available-to-Promise (ATP) check is a real-time process that determines if the requested material will be available on the requested date. It doesn't just look at current stock; it's a dynamic calculation that considers:

  • Current unrestricted stock
  • Inbound movements (e.g., planned production orders, purchase orders)
  • Outbound movements (e.g., other sales orders, reservations)

The rules governing this check are defined by the Checking Group in the material master and the Checking Rule from the SD transaction (e.g., 'A' for sales order). Together, they determine the scope of the check.

S/4HANA introduces Advanced ATP (aATP), which offers more sophisticated features like real-time, multi-level checks and intelligent backorder processing.

Backorder Processing: When new stock arrives, a backorder processing run can automatically re-evaluate open sales orders and re-confirm them against the new inventory, potentially improving delivery dates for high-priority customers.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing ATP

Configuring the ATP check is a cross-functional effort involving SD and MM/PP consultants.

  • Define Checking Groups: SPRO -> ... -> Basic Functions -> Availability Check and Transfer of Requirements -> Availability Check -> Availability Check with ATP Logic or Against Planning -> Define Checking Groups.
  • Define Checking Rule for Backorders: SAP GUI OMIH. Path: ... -> Determine Rule for Control of Backorder Processing. This is where you assign a checking rule per plant for backorder processing runs.

3.2. Delivery Scheduling

Concept: Delivery Scheduling calculates the actual dates for the entire shipping process. The system performs backward scheduling from the customer's requested delivery date to determine if it's feasible.

It calculates the following key dates:

  1. Goods Issue Date: The day the goods must leave the plant.
  2. Loading Date: When loading must begin.
  3. Material Availability Date: The latest date the material must be available for picking and packing to start.
  4. Transportation Planning Date: When transportation planning must begin.

This calculation depends on several factors:

  • Transit Time: Time from your plant to the customer (from the Route).
  • Loading Time: Time to load the truck (from the Shipping Point).
  • Pick/Pack Time: Time to gather and pack the goods (from the Shipping Point).

Scheduling Control:

  • By Sales Document Type: You can switch scheduling on or off for an entire document type. For example, you would enable it for a standard order (OR) but disable it for a contract (CQ), as a contract doesn't trigger an immediate delivery.
  • By Shipping Point: Each shipping point can have its own working hours (via a Factory Calendar) and default times for picking, packing, and loading, making the calculation highly specific to the fulfillment location.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing Scheduling

  • Activate for Sales Doc Type: SAP GUI OVLY. Path: ... -> Basic Functions -> Delivery Scheduling and Transportation Scheduling -> Define Scheduling By Sales Document Type.
  • Define for Shipping Point: SAP GUI OVLZ. Path: ... -> Logistics Execution -> Shipping -> Basic Shipping Functions -> Scheduling -> Delivery Scheduling and Transportation Scheduling -> Define Scheduling By Shipping Point.

3.3. Controlling Procurement and Delivery: Schedule Line Categories

Concept: If the Item Category controls the what of a line item, the Schedule Line Category controls the when and how of its fulfillment. For each item in a sales order, there can be one or more schedule lines, each with a date and a confirmed quantity.

The Schedule Line Category determines:

  • Is this schedule line relevant for delivery?
  • Does it generate a transfer of requirements to planning (MRP)?
  • Does it trigger a specific inventory movement type (e.g., 601 for goods issue for a delivery)?
  • Can it be part of an availability check?

Common Standard Schedule Line Categories:

  • CP: Standard. Relevant for MRP and delivery.
  • CN: No MRP, no delivery. Used for items that are not planned or shipped (like services).
  • DN: Returns. Used in return orders to manage the inbound goods movement.
  • CB: Individual Purchase Order. This schedule line will automatically trigger the creation of a purchase requisition to procure the goods specifically for this sales order.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing Schedule Line Categories

  • Define Schedule Line Categories: SAP GUI VOV6. Path: Sales and Distribution -> Sales -> Sales Documents -> Schedule Lines -> Define Schedule Line Categories.
  • Assignment: The system determines the schedule line category based on the Item Category and the MRP type from the material master. This is configured in SAP GUI VOV5. Path: ... -> Schedule Lines -> Assign Schedule Line Categories.

Chapter 4: Logistics and Fulfillment (LE, EWM, TM)

With a confirmed sales order in hand, the process moves from Sales to Logistics. The goal is to physically pick, pack, and ship the goods to the customer.

4.1. Creating the Outbound Delivery

The outbound delivery document is the starting point for all shipping activities. It contains all the data needed for picking, packing, goods issue, and transportation planning.

How-To: Create an Outbound Delivery

  1. App: Use the Create Outbound Deliveries from Sales Orders Fiori app. This app provides a worklist of sales orders due for shipment.
  2. Enter your Shipping Point and the selection dates.
  3. The system displays a list of open sales order items ready for delivery.
  4. Select the items you want to deliver and click Create Deliveries.
  5. The system creates the outbound delivery document(s).

4.2. Applying Brakes: Delivery Blocks

Based on source document: Définir motif blocage liv.doc

Concept: A Delivery Block is a mechanism to temporarily halt the shipping process for a specific order or even a single schedule line. The block can be set manually by a user or automatically by the system.

Common Reasons for a Delivery Block:

  • 01: For commercial approval
  • 02: Credit limit exceeded (often set automatically)
  • 03: Price not available
  • 06: Political reasons

A delivery block prevents the creation of an outbound delivery document. The block must be removed in the sales order before the logistics process can continue.

How it's Used:

  • Header Level: Set in the sales order header (in the Billing Document tab), it blocks the entire order.
  • Schedule Line Level: A block can also be set for a specific schedule line, allowing other parts of the order to be delivered. This is useful if one item is on hold but others are cleared for shipment.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing Delivery Blocks

  • Define Delivery Blocks: SAP GUI OVLS. Path: Logistics Execution -> Shipping -> Deliveries -> Define Reasons for Blocking in Shipping.
  • Here you can define the block reasons and specify their impact. For example, you can have a block that stops delivery creation but still allows requirements to be passed to MRP.

4.3. Warehouse and Transportation Processing (EWM & TM)

Once the outbound delivery is created, it flows into the warehouse and transportation systems.

  • Extended Warehouse Management (EWM):
    1. The outbound delivery triggers the creation of a Warehouse Request in EWM.
    2. This leads to the creation of Warehouse Tasks (e.g., picking tasks).
    3. A warehouse operator, often using an RF scanner, executes the tasks: picking the goods from a storage bin.
    4. The goods are brought to a packing station where they are packed into Handling Units (HUs), like boxes or pallets.
    5. The packed goods are moved to the goods issue area.
  • Transportation Management (TM):
    1. The outbound delivery creates a Freight Unit in TM.
    2. The planner combines freight units into a Freight Order.
    3. The planner performs carrier selection and tenders the freight order to a shipping company.

4.4. Post Goods Issue (PGI)

This is the final step in the shipping process. Posting the goods issue legally transfers ownership of the goods and has significant financial implications.

Key Impacts of PGI:

  • Inventory Reduction: The stock of the material is reduced in inventory management (MM).
  • Financial Posting: A financial journal entry is created automatically:
    • Credit (-) Inventory Account
    • Debit (+) Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) Account
  • Delivery Status Update: The status of the outbound delivery is updated to "Completed."
  • Billing Due List: The delivery document is now ready for invoicing and will appear on the billing due list.

How-To: Post Goods Issue

PGI can be done from several Fiori apps, including Manage Outbound Deliveries or directly by the EWM system upon confirmation of loading.

Chapter 5: Billing and Financial Integration

The final step in the O2C process is to invoice the customer and receive payment.

5.1. Creating the Customer Invoice

The billing document is created by referencing the outbound delivery (for goods) or the sales order (for services).

How-To: Create an Invoice

  1. App: Use the Create Billing Documents Fiori app.
  2. The app presents a worklist of documents due for billing (the Billing Due List).
  3. Select the deliveries or sales orders you want to invoice.
  4. The system creates the billing documents. You can review them before saving.
  5. Upon saving, the invoice is created.

5.2. The Financial Impact

Saving the billing document triggers another automatic, real-time integration with Finance:

  • Debit (+) Customer Accounts Receivable (AR) sub-ledger. This means the customer now owes you money.
  • Credit (-) Sales Revenue Account.
  • Credit (-) Tax Payable Account.

A corresponding journal entry is posted automatically in the Universal Journal.

5.3. Receiving Customer Payment

The final step is processing the incoming payment from the customer, which clears the open receivable on their account. This is typically handled by the Accounts Receivable department using Fiori apps like Post Incoming Payments.

entry.title: Re: Contacts showing private vs public
entry.content:
Public contacts are users who have registered with the Ariba Network (SAP Business Network) and are linked to the supplier’s account. When a contact is created by the supplier in the Ariba Network and is synchronized with your sourcing project, they appear as “public.”
Their details are visible and managed centrally by the supplier’s Ariba Network administrator. Updates to their information must be made in the Ariba Network.

Private contacts are created directly within your Ariba Sourcing project or Ariba SLP (Supplier Lifecycle & Performance) site. These contacts are not yet registered or linked to the supplier’s Ariba Network account.
Their details are only visible within your site and are not synchronized with the supplier’s Ariba Network profile. You can edit their information locally.

Source of Creation:
If a contact is created in the Ariba Network and then pulled into Sourcing, it’s public.
If a contact is created directly in Sourcing or SLP, it’s private until the contact registers with the Ariba Network and is linked to the supplier’s account.

Synchronization:
Only contacts who have completed registration and linkage with the supplier’s Ariba Network account become public.
Contacts who have not completed this process remain private.
User Actions:
Sometimes, a sourcing manager or buyer adds a contact manually for a specific event or project. These remain private unless the contact is invited to register and completes the process.
Public contacts are managed by the supplier in the Ariba Network and are visible across all projects.

Private contacts are local to your sourcing project or SLP and are not visible to the supplier until they register and are linked.

If you want a private contact to become public, you need to invite them to register with the Ariba Network and ensure the supplier administrator approves the linkage.

entry.title: The Ultimate Guide to Subcontracting in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Chapter 1: The Foundation - Master Data

Before you can execute any process, the correct master data must be in place. This is the bedrock of the subcontracting process in SAP.

1.1 Material Master

You need at least two types of materials: the finished product you receive from the subcontractor and the components you provide to them.

  • Finished Product (e.g., PH-K1000, "PharmaCo Drug Kit, Assembled")
    • MRP 2 View: In the Procurement section, set the Special Procurement key to 30 (Subcontracting). This tells the system that this material is procured via a subcontracting process when a requirement is generated by the planning run (MRP).
    • Purchasing View: Ensure the "Purchasing" view is maintained for the relevant plant.
    • Fiori App: Manage Product Master Data (App ID F1602)
    • Key Views & Fields:
  • Component Materials (e.g., PH-C100, "Drug Vial"; PH-C200, "Packaging Box")
    • These are standard materials that will be provisioned. Ensure they have Basic Data, Purchasing, and Plant/Storage Location views maintained. They are managed as regular inventory items.
    • Fiori App: Manage Product Master Data (App ID F1602)
    • Key Views & Fields:

1.2 Bill of Materials (BOM)

The BOM lists all the components and their quantities required to produce the finished product. SAP uses this to automatically determine which components to provide to the subcontractor.

  • Fiori App: Maintain Bill of Material (App ID F2260) / SAP GUI: CS01
  • How-To:
    1. Enter the Material number of the finished product (e.g., PH-K1000).
    2. Enter the Plant and a BOM Usage of 1 (Production).
    3. On the next screen, list each Component (e.g., PH-C100, PH-C200) and the required Quantity.
    4. Save the BOM.

When a subcontracting purchase order is created for the finished product, the system will automatically read this BOM to populate the list of components to be provided1.

1.3 Purchasing Info Record

The info record stores the specific relationship between a material, a supplier, and a plant for purchasing. For subcontracting, it holds the price the supplier charges for their service.

  • Fiori App: Manage Purchasing Info Records (App ID F1999) / SAP GUI: ME11
  • How-To:
    1. Enter the Supplier and the Material number of the finished product (e.g., PH-K1000).
    2. Select the Subcontracting info category.
    3. In the Purchasing Org. Data 1 tab, enter the subcontractor's service Price. This is not the price of the material, but the price for the assembly or sorting service. 2
    4. Save the Info Record.

1.4 Business Partner (Supplier)

The subcontractor must exist in the system as a Business Partner with a Supplier role.

  • Fiori App: Manage Business Partner Master Data (App ID F3163)
  • How-To: Ensure the subcontractor is created with a Supplier role and extended to the relevant Company Code (for invoicing) and Purchasing Organization (for ordering).

Chapter 2: The End-to-End Subcontracting Process Flow

This chapter details the step-by-step operational flow, from identifying a need to paying the subcontractor.

Step 1: Create the Subcontracting Purchase Order (PO)

The process begins with a formal order to the subcontractor. This can be created manually or automatically from a purchase requisition generated by an MRP run.

  • Fiori App: Manage Purchase Orders (App ID F0842A) / SAP GUI: ME21N
  • How-To:
    1. Create a new Purchase Order using the standard

Order Type 'NB'3.

    1. Enter the Supplier and other header details.
    2. In the item overview, enter the Material number of the finished product (e.g., PH-K1000).
    3. Crucially, set the

Item Category to L (Subcontracting)4.

    1. Enter the required Quantity and Delivery Date.
    2. Navigate to the "Material Data" tab at the item detail level. Click the "Components" or "BOM Explosion" button. The system will automatically populate the components and quantities from the BOM you created earlier. 5
    3. Save the Purchase Order.

Step 2: Provide Components to the Subcontractor

You must physically send the components to the subcontractor. In SAP, this is recorded as a transfer posting, not a sale. The components remain your company's property6.

  • Fiori App: Monitor Subcontracting Documents (App ID F2356) / SAP GUI: ME2O
  • How-To (Monitoring):
    1. Use the Monitor Subcontracting Documents app to see which components are due to be sent to which suppliers. This gives you a clear overview of requirements.
  • How-To (Posting the Goods Issue):
    1. From the monitoring report, select the components you are shipping.
    2. Click "Post Goods Issue".
    3. The system will propose the movement. The standard movement type is 541, which transfers stock from your plant's unrestricted-use stock to the special "Stock Provided to Vendor." This transfer is a logistical movement and has no financial impact at this stage.
    4. This step can be performed using handheld RF scanners in a warehouse environment (as referenced by "lecteurs HF" 7), which would typically call a simplified transaction that posts the 541 movement in the background.
  • Checking the Stock: You can view this special stock segment using the Stock - Single Material Fiori app (App ID F1595) or MMBE in the GUI. The stock will appear under a line item called "Stck w. Subcontr." (Stock with Subcontractor). This stock is still valuated as part of your inventory. 8

Step 3: Receive the Finished Product from the Subcontractor

Once the subcontractor completes their work (e.g., assembly), they ship the finished product back to you. You record this as a Goods Receipt (GR).

  • Fiori App: Post Goods Receipt for Purchasing Document (App ID F0843) / SAP GUI: MIGO
  • How-To:
    1. Select Goods Receipt against a Purchase Order.
    2. Enter the Subcontracting PO number.
    3. The system will display the finished product. Enter the Quantity received.
    4. If the components were batch-managed, you

must specify which batches and quantities of components were consumed by the subcontractor to produce the finished goods9. This information should be provided by the supplier on their delivery note.

    1. Post the Goods Receipt.
  • Behind the Scenes (Automatic Postings): When you post the GR, SAP automatically performs two movements:
    • Movement Type 101 (+): Receipt of the finished product into your inventory. This increases the stock of the finished good.
    • Movement Type 543 (-): Consumption of the components from the "Stock Provided to Vendor." This decreases the component stock at the supplier. This is known as backflushing. 10

Step 4: Invoice Verification

The final step is to receive and post the invoice from the subcontractor for their service fee.

  • Fiori App: Create Supplier Invoice (App ID F0859) / SAP GUI: MIRO
  • How-To:
    1. Enter the invoice details (date, amount, etc.).
    2. Reference the Subcontracting Purchase Order.
    3. The system will propose the amount based on the service price in the PO and the quantity received.
    4. Verify the details and post the invoice. This creates a payable to the supplier.

Chapter 3: Special Scenario - Subcontracting for Rework/Sorting

Sometimes, you need to send a product to a subcontractor not for assembly, but for a rework or sorting activity. For example, a batch of finished product failed inspection and needs to be sorted to separate the good items from the bad.

In this scenario, the "finished product" you receive back is essentially the same item you sent as a "component."

Process Steps for Rework:

The process is nearly identical to standard subcontracting, with one key difference in the Purchase Order creation.

  1. Create the Rework PO:
    • PO Item: Material PH-K1000, Quantity 95.
    • PO Component: Material PH-K1000, Quantity 100.
    • Use Item Category 'L' as usual.
    • The material number you enter in the item line will be the material being reworked (e.g., PH-K1000).
    • Navigate to the Components tab.
    • SAP might try to explode a BOM. You must manually adjust this. Delete any components that are not relevant.
    • Add the same material number (PH-K1000) as a component. The quantity of the component will be the number of units you are sending for sorting. 11
    • Example: You are sending 100 units of PH-K1000 for sorting, and you expect to receive 95 good units back.
  2. Provide "Component" for Rework: Post a Goods Issue (Movement Type 541) to send the 100 units of PH-K1000 to the subcontractor's stock.
  3. Receive Reworked Product: Post a Goods Receipt (Movement Type 101) for the 95 good units of PH-K1000. The system will automatically consume the 100 units from the subcontractor stock (Movement Type 543). The 5 "lost" units are effectively scrapped during consumption.
  4. Invoice Verification: Pay the supplier for the sorting service.

Chapter 4: Integration with Other Modules

Subcontracting is not an isolated process. It integrates tightly with other SAP S/4HANA modules.

  • Warehouse Management (EWM):
    • When you post the 541 Goods Issue, EWM creates an Outbound Delivery Order to pick and stage the components.
    • The GR (101 movement) triggers an Inbound Delivery in EWM, which is then used for putaway of the finished goods into the warehouse.
  • Quality Management (QM):
    • You can activate a QM inspection for the finished product. When the GR is posted, the system automatically creates an inspection lot. The stock is posted to "Quality Inspection" stock until a usage decision is made.
  • Finance & Controlling (FI/CO):
    • Debit: Finished Good Inventory Account (for the value of the components + service cost).
    • Credit: Component Inventory Account (for the value of components consumed).
    • Credit: GR/IR (Goods Receipt/Invoice Receipt) Clearing Account (for the subcontracting service cost).
    • Debit: GR/IR Clearing Account.
    • Credit: Vendor Payables Account.
    • Component GI (541): No accounting document. It's a logistical transfer within the same company's valuated stock.
    • Finished Good GR (101/543):
    • Invoice Receipt (MIRO):

Chapter 5: Customizing Points (For Consultants)

While standard SAP works well, customization may be needed. This is done in the SPRO transaction (on-premise) or the Manage Your Solution app (Cloud).

  • Special Procurement Key:
    • Path: SPRO -> Materials Management -> Consumption-Based Planning -> Master Data -> Define Special Procurement Types
    • Here you can review the settings for key '30' (Subcontracting) or create new ones if needed.
  • PO Document Types & Item Categories:
    • Path: SPRO -> Materials Management -> Purchasing -> Purchase Order -> Define Document Types / Define Item Categories
    • Review settings for document type 'NB' and item category 'L'.
  • Movement Types:
    • Path: SPRO -> Materials Management -> Inventory Management and Physical Inventory -> Movement Types -> Copy, Change Movement Types
    • Here you can analyze the settings for 541, 543, and 101, such as the account modifications that drive the financial postings.

Chapter 6: Comprehensive Test Plan

This test plan provides realistic, step-by-step exercises to validate the end-to-end subcontracting process.

Test Scenario 1: Standard Assembly Subcontracting

  • Objective: To test the complete process of sending multiple components to a supplier for assembly into a finished product.
  • Business Case: PharmaCo needs to assemble 50 "Drug Kits" (PH-K1000). The kit consists of 1 Drug Vial (PH-C100) and 1 Packaging Box (PH-C200). The service is performed by supplier SUB-EAST-01.

Test Prerequisites (Master Data):

  1. Finished Good: Material PH-K1000 created with Special Procurement Key 30.
  2. Components: Materials PH-C100 and PH-C200 exist.
  3. BOM: A production BOM exists for PH-K1000 containing 1x PH-C100 and 1x PH-C200.
  4. Info Record: A subcontracting info record exists for PH-K1000 and supplier SUB-EAST-01 with a service price of €5.00 per kit.
  5. Stock: At least 50 units of PH-C100 and 50 units of PH-C200 are available in unrestricted-use stock.

Test Steps & Expected Results:

Step

Action

Fiori App / T-Code

Expected Result

1

Create a Subcontracting PO for 50 units of PH-K1000 for supplier SUB-EAST-01. Use Item Category 'L'.

Manage Purchase Orders (F0842A)

A PO is created. The "Components" tab should automatically show 50 units of PH-C100 and 50 units of PH-C200. The PO price should be €250 (50 x €5.00).

2

Monitor subcontracting requirements for supplier SUB-EAST-01.

Monitor Subcontracting Documents (F2356)

The app should show a requirement of 50 units for both components, linked to the PO created in Step 1.

3

Post the Goods Issue for both components to the subcontractor.

Monitor Subcontracting Documents (F2356) or MIGO

A material document is created with Movement Type 541. The stock of PH-C100 and PH-C200 should decrease by 50 in plant stock and increase by 50 in "Stock Provided to Vendor." No accounting document is created.

4

Check the stock overview for the components.

Stock - Single Material (F1595) or MMBE

For PH-C100 and PH-C200, you should see a line for "Stck w. Subcontr." with a quantity of 50.

5

Receive 48 finished kits (PH-K1000) from the subcontractor (simulating a partial delivery).

Post Goods Receipt for Purchasing Document (F0843)

A material document is created. Movement 101: Stock of PH-K1000 increases by 48. Movement 543: "Stock Provided to Vendor" for PH-C100 and PH-C200 decreases by 48. An accounting document is created to reflect the inventory value change.

6

Post the supplier invoice for the 48 kits received.

Create Supplier Invoice (F0859)

An invoice document is created for €240 (48 x €5.00). A payable is posted to the supplier's account, and the GR/IR account is cleared.

Test Scenario 2: Rework/Sorting Subcontracting

  • Objective: To validate the process of sending a batch of a single product for sorting and receiving the good units back.
  • Business Case: A batch of 100 "Drug Kits" (PH-K1000) has suspected packaging defects. They are sent to supplier SUB-EAST-01 for sorting. The supplier is expected to recover 90 good kits.

Test Prerequisites (Master Data):

  1. Material: PH-K1000 exists.
  2. Info Record: A subcontracting info record for PH-K1000 and supplier SUB-EAST-01 exists with a sorting service price of €1.50 per unit handled.
  3. Stock: At least 100 units of PH-K1000 are available in unrestricted-use stock.

Test Steps & Expected Results:

Step

Action

Fiori App / T-Code

Expected Result

1

Create a Subcontracting PO. Item: PH-K1000, Qty: 90. Item Category: 'L'.

Manage Purchase Orders (F0842A)

A PO is created.

2

Manually adjust the components in the PO. Remove any auto-populated items and add a single component line: Component: PH-K1000, Required Qty: 100.

Manage Purchase Orders (F0842A)

The PO now correctly reflects that 100 units will be provided to get 90 back. 12

3

Post Goods Issue of 100 units of PH-K1000 to the subcontractor.

MIGO (Mvt 541)

A material document is posted. 100 units of PH-K1000 move from unrestricted to "Stock Provided to Vendor."

4

Receive the 90 sorted "good" units of PH-K1000.

Post Goods Receipt for Purchasing Document (F0843)

A material document is created. Movement 101: Stock of PH-K1000 increases by 90. Movement 543: "Stock Provided to Vendor" for PH-K1000 is consumed by 100. The 10 "lost" units are effectively scrapped from a stock perspective. An accounting document is posted.

5

Post the supplier invoice for the sorting service on 100 units.

Create Supplier Invoice (F0859)

An invoice document is created for €150 (100 units handled * €1.50). A payable is posted to the supplier's account.
